store, to be located within three hundred feet (300') of any public or private
school or church property primarily and regularly used for worship services and
religious activities. The distance indicated in this section shall be measured
from the nearest property line of such public or private school or church to
the nearest perimeter wall of the premises of any such mixed beverage, bottle
club or beer and wine establishment or retail package store which has been
licensed to sell alcoholic beverages. The provisions of this section shall not
apply to mixed beverage, bottle club or beer and wine establishments which have
been licensed to sell alcoholic beverages for on premises consumption or retail
package stores prior to November 1, 2000; provided, if at the time of
application for license renewal the licensed location has not been in actual
operation for a continuous period of more than sixty (60) days, the license
shall not be renewed. If any school or church shall be established within three
hundred feet (300') of any retail package store, mixed beverage, bottle club or
beer and wine establishment subject to the provisions of this section after
such retail package store, mixed beverage, bottle club or beer and wine
establishment has been licensed, the provisions of this section shall not be a
deterrent to the renewal of such license if there has not been a lapse of more
than sixty (60) days. When any mixed beverage, bottle club or beer and wine
establishment subject to the provisions of this section which has a license to
sell alcoholic beverages for on premises consumption or retail package store
changes ownership or the operator thereof is changed and such change of
ownership results in the same type of business being conducted on the premises,
the provisions of this section shall not be a deterrent to the issuance of a
license to the new owner or operator if he or she is otherwise qualified. (Ord.
2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
4-2-8: RETAIL PACKAGE STORES; REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Separated Premises Required: The premises of a retail package store
shall be separated from the premises in which any other goods, wares, or
merchandise are sold or services are rendered, by nontransparent walls which
may be broken by a passageway to which the public is not admitted for the
purpose of selling, reselling, or delivering in connection with the sale of the
alcoholic beverages.
   B.   Days And Hours Of Sales: It is unlawful for any person holding a
license for a retail package store or any employee or agent thereof to keep the
premises of the retail package store open for the purpose of selling, or to
sell, any alcoholic beverages at any hour other than between the hours of ten
o'clock (10:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M., Monday through Saturday; or
on the day of any general, primary, runoff primary, or special election, while
the polls are open, whether on a national, State, County or City election; or
on New Year's Day, Memorial Day, the Fourth of July, Labor Day, Veterans Day,
Thanksgiving Day, or Christmas Day.
   C.   Conditions Of Sales: Retail package stores may sell alcoholic beverages
only in retail containers in the original package for consumption off the
premises. Alcoholic beverages may be sold only at ordinary room temperatures.
(Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
4-2-9: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS 1 :
It is unlawful for any person:
   A.   Knowingly to sell, deliver, or furnish alcoholic beverages to any
person under twenty one (21) years of age;
   B.   Who is under the age of twenty one (21) to misrepresent his age in
writing or by presenting documentation of age for the purpose of inducing any
person to sell him alcoholic beverages;
   C.   To employ any person under the age of twenty one (21) years in the
selling or handling of alcoholic beverages;
   D.   Who is a licensee or an agent or employee thereof to permit any person
under twenty one (21) years of age to enter into, remain within, or loiter
about a licensed premises;
   E.   Knowingly to sell, deliver, or furnish alcoholic beverages to an
intoxicated person or to any person who has been adjudged mentally challenged;
   F.   To open a retail container or consume alcoholic beverages on the
premises of a retail package store, or for any operator of a retail package
store, or any person in charge thereof, to permit any person to open a retail
container therein or consume alcoholic beverages therein;
   G.   To transport in any moving vehicle, upon any public highway, street,
alley or roadway within the corporate limits of the City, or in or upon any
property owned by the City outside of its corporate limits, any alcoholic
beverages, except in the original container which shall not have been opened
and from which the original cap or seal shall not have been removed, unless the
opened container is in the rear trunk or rear compartment, which shall include
the spare tire compartment in a station wagon or panel truck, or any outside
compartment which is not accessible to the driver or any other person in the
vehicle while it is in motion;
   H.   Import into this State, except as provided from in the Oklahoma
Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, any alcoholic beverages; provided, that nothing
herein shall prohibit the importation or possession for personal use of not
more than one liter (1 L) of alcoholic beverages upon which the Oklahoma Excise
Tax is delinquent;
   I.   Receive, possess, or use any alcoholic beverage in violation of the
provisions of the Oklahoma Alcoholic Beverage Control Act;
   J.   To consume spirits or intoxicating liquor in public or to be
intoxicated in a public place;
   K.   Who is the operator of a cafe, restaurant, club, or any place of
recreation, to permit any person to be drunk or intoxicated in such place of
business;
   L.   For any person to loiter in any place where alcohol of any kind is
bartered, sold, given away or otherwise furnished contrary to law;
   M.   No owner, operator, partner, manager or person having supervisory
control of any establishment licensed to sell or serve intoxicating beverages
shall permit any of the following on or about any commercial premises where
intoxicating beverages are dispensed or consumed:
      1.   The performance by any person of acts, or simulated acts of sexual
intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or
any sexual act which are otherwise prohibited by law;
      2.   The actual intentional touching or caressing or fondling by any
person of the breast, anus or genitals;
      3.   Any person on the licensed premises while such person is unclothed
or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose to view any portion of the
areola of the female breast or any portions of the pubic hair, buttocks or
genitals;
      4.   Any person to perform acts of, or acts which simulate sexual acts
which are prohibited by law, or permit any person to use artificial devices or
inanimate objects to depict any prohibited activities or permit the showing of
films, still pictures, electronic reproductions or other visual reproductions
depicting any of the prohibited activities described in this subsection. (Ord.
2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  5-2-3A2 and section 6-5D-3 of this Code.
4-2-10: ANNUAL REPORT TO STATE:
The City Clerk shall make an annual report as of the close of business on June
30 each year to the Oklahoma Alcoholic Beverage Laws Enforcement Commission
showing the number and class of licenses issued and the amount of money
received therefrom. (Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
4-2-11: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY:
   A.   Suit: All sums due from any person, firm or corporation by reason of
license fees imposed by this chapter and all penalties accruing from such
person by reason of failure to pay such fee shall be recoverable at the suit of
the City brought against such person, firm or corporation in any court of
competent jurisdiction. In any such suit, in addition to the fee and penalties,
the plaintiff shall recover interest, at the rate of ten percent (10%) per
annum, upon all sums due by way of fee and penalty from the date of accrual
thereof, and all costs of collection, judicial or otherwise, including
reasonable attorney fees, all to be determined by the court. Prosecution for an
offense against the City arising out of the failure to pay a fee required
herein, regardless of the outcome thereof or of its continued pendency, shall
not constitute a defense or a bar in any manner to the collection of the fee
and penalties, if any are due, as herein provided.
   B.   Penalty: Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
CHAPTER 3
RETAIL BEER AND WINE
SECTION:

4-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the terms defined in section
4-2-1 of this title shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them.
(Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
4-3-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any retail dealer, whether permanent or temporary, to sell,
distribute, or dispense any wine or beer without having first received a
Municipal license as herein required. (Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-
2018)
4-3-3: LICENSE FEE:
   A.   Fee Established: The annual license fee for a retail dealer selling
beer and wine shall be as follows:
 
Beer and wine                    $175.00
Certificate of Compliance Letter 25.00
 
   B.   Payment Of Fee: The Municipal license and certificate of compliance
letter fees shall be paid to the City Clerk at the time of issuance of the
certificate of compliance letter and the license and in the manner prescribed
herein. (Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
4-3-4: COMPLIANCE WITH LAW:
No Municipal license shall be issued to any retail dealer by the City Clerk
without a satisfactory showing that the applicant has obtained all State and
County licenses and permits required by law, and has in all other respects
complied with the State and local alcoholic beverage control requirements.
(Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
4-3-5: APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE LETTER; LICENSE; ISSUANCE:
   A.   A person desiring to engage in any of the businesses mentioned in this
chapter or apply for a renewal of a license within the City shall make
application as required by title 37A of the Oklahoma Statutes, except for a
special event, and shall be required to furnish the Alcoholic Beverage Laws
Enforcement Commission a Certificate of Compliance Letter with Zoning, Fire and
Health Codes.
      1.   Application And Fee: Application for such certificate shall be in
writing on a form provided by the Lone Grove City Clerk. At the time that the
Certificate of Compliance Letter is provided each applicant shall pay the
required fee as established within this chapter.
      2.   Compliance: In order to apply and receive a Certificate of
Compliance Letter a local business must verify that they comply with all the
Municipality Zoning, Fire Codes and the State of Oklahoma Health Codes.
      3.   Inspection Form: The City will provide a certificate of compliance
inspection form to all local businesses wishing to apply for a certificate of
compliance letter.
      4.   Signatures: The above certificate of compliance letter shall be
signed by the City Clerk; Code Enforcement Officer or their designee.
   B.   Once a local business has been issued a State of Oklahoma license from
the ABLE Commission they will return to the City of Lone Grove for the issuance
of a City license and pay to the City Clerk the required license fee. If the
applicant holds a valid State license to engage in the business within the City
issued by the Director of the Oklahoma Alcoholic Beverage Laws Enforcement
Commission, if the application is in accordance with this chapter, and if the
applicant has paid the required City license fee, then the City Clerk shall
issue the license applied for.
   C.   The City Clerk is hereby authorized and directed to issue the
appropriate license to any qualified applicant or business outlined in this
chapter. (Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
4-3-6: EXPIRATION OF LICENSE; FEE DUE DATE:
All licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall expire on June 30 of the
year for which issued, and the fee shall be paid annually on or before July 1.
The cost of a license for any type of business applied for during the fiscal
year shall be a pro rata part of the cost of the yearly license, computed on a
monthly basis. Licenses issued on or after the fifteenth day of any month shall
be charged for on the basis of the first day of the next month. (Ord. 2018-273,
9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
4-3-7: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
The licensee receiving a license pursuant to this chapter shall post his fee
receipt in a conspicuous place in or upon the premises wherein the licensed
occupation is carried on. (Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
4-3-8: DAYS AND HOURS OF SALES:
   A.   Sales For On Premises Consumption: It is unlawful for any person, firm,
or corporation to sell wine or beer for on premises consumption between the
hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. Sunday and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. on the
following Monday; and on any other days of the week between the hours of two
o'clock (2:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
   B.   Sales For Off Premises Consumption: It is unlawful for any person,
firm, or corporation to sell wine or beer for off premises consumption between
the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of the same
day. (Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
4-3-9: MINORS:
   A.   Sale To; Purchase By: It is unlawful for any person, firm or
corporation to sell, offer for sale, give away, procure for, or otherwise
dispense to any minor wine or beer; or for any minor to purchase, receive or
procure any wine or beer.
   B.   Possession 1 : It is unlawful and an offense for any minor to be in
possession of any wine or beer while such person is on any public street, road
or highway, or in any public building or place.
   C.   Employment: It is unlawful for any owner, manager, or operator of a
place where wine or beer is sold for consumption on the premises, except an
eating place where the service of wine or beer is incidental to the main
business of serving food, to employ a minor to work in such place.
   D.   Presence On Premises: If the premises of a holder of a license to sell
wine or beer contains a separate or enclosed bar area which has as its main
purpose the sale or serving of wine or beer for consumption on the premises, no
person under twenty one (21) years of age shall enter, attempt to enter, or
remain in said area. The provisions of this subsection shall not prohibit
persons under twenty one (21) years of age from entering or remaining in an
area which has as its main purpose some objective other than the sale or
serving of wine or beer, in which sales or serving of said beverage is
incidental to the main purpose, if the persons under twenty one (21) years of
age are not sold or served or do not consume wine or beer anywhere on the
premises; however, the incidental service of food in the bar area shall not
exempt persons under twenty one (21) years of age from the provisions of this
subsection. (Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  6-5D-2 of this Code.
4-3-10: INTOXICATED PERSONS:
It is unlawful for the owner, manager, or operator of a place where wine or
beer is sold for consumption on the premises to sell or otherwise furnish wine
or beer to an intoxicated person or to permit an intoxicated person to remain
or loiter therein. (Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
4-3-11: CONDUCT OF BUSINESS:
   A.   It is unlawful for the owner, manager, or operator of such a place to
permit therein gambling, betting, operation of a lottery; selling, furnishing,
or drinking of alcoholic beverages; disorderly conduct; loud or disturbing
language, noise, or music; profane language; or any other violation of the laws
of the State or of the ordinances of the City, or for any person to engage in
any such activity or conduct in such a place.
   B.   It is unlawful for the owner, manager, or operator of such a place to
permit therein fighting, boxing, wrestling, or other contests of physical
strength; or for any person to fight, box, wrestle, or engage in other contests
of physical strength in such a place. (Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-
2018)
4-3-12: DRINKING IN PUBLIC:
It is unlawful for any person to drink any wine or beer while such person is
upon any public street, alley, or other public highway, or in any public
building or other public place within the City. This section shall not prohibit
a person who is of age from drinking wine or beer in a place licensed to sell
wine or beer for consumption on the premises. (Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff.
9-17-2018)
4-3-13: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The City Council shall have power, after public hearing, to revoke any license
granted hereunder for violation of law or ordinance by the license holder.
(Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
4-3-14: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 2018-273, 9-17-2018, eff. 9-17-2018)
CHAPTER 4
SOLICITORS
SECTION:
4-4-1: Definition
4-4-2: Permit Required; Fee
4-4-3: Tax Identification Number Required
4-4-4: Term Of Permit; Hours Soliciting Permitted
4-4-5: Uninvited Soliciting
4-4-6: Penalty; Revocation Of Permit
4-4-1: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this chapter, "solicitor" means a person, firm, or
corporation soliciting commercial orders for goods or services which are to be
provided either from stocks or goods carried with a person or services provided
at the time the order is made, or for goods or services which are to be
provided or shipped to the consumer at a later date. (1990 Code § 9-101)
4-4-2: PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE:
Any solicitor, prior to soliciting or canvassing within the corporate limits,
must first obtain a permit from the City Clerk and pay a fee of twenty dollars
($20.00) per week or sixty dollars ($60.00) per thirty (30) days. An individual
permit must be obtained by each solicitor. (Ord. 2017-267, 7-17-2017, eff. 8-1-
2017)
4-4-3: TAX IDENTIFICATION NUMBER REQUIRED:
An applicant for a solicitor's permit must furnish to the City Clerk a current
sales tax identification number issued by the Oklahoma Tax Commission. In the
event no number is provided, the Clerk shall not issue the permit. (1990 Code §
9-104)
4-4-4: TERM OF PERMIT; HOURS SOLICITING PERMITTED:
The soliciting permit shall entitle the solicitor to solicit or canvass within
the corporate limits for a period not to exceed the number of days stated on
the permit, and between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M., and extending
through eight o'clock (8:00) P.M., each day of the week, excluding Sunday.
(1990 Code § 9-103; amd. 2006 Code; Ord. 2017-267, 7-17-2017, eff. 8-1-2017)
4-4-5: UNINVITED SOLICITING:
The practice of going in and upon private residences in the City by solicitors
of merchandise and service, not having been requested or invited to do so by
the owner or occupant of said private residence, for the purpose of soliciting
orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise, or services, or for the
purpose of disposing the same, is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and
punishable as such nuisance as an offense. The Chief of Police is hereby
required and directed to suppress the same and to abate such nuisance as is
described in title 5, chapter 2 of this Code. Nonprofit and civic organizations
are excluded. (2006 Code)
4-4-6: PENALTY; REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
Any person, firm, entity, corporation, association, partnership or group which
solicits or canvasses in the City without first obtaining a permit as provided
herein shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction of same, shall
be subject to a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense.
In addition, the City Council, after hearing and notice, shall have the right
to revoke any permit issued. (1990 Code § 9-105)
CHAPTER 5
VEHICLES FOR HIRE
ARTICLE A.  USE OF PUBLIC WAYS; PERMIT REQUIREMENTS
SECTION:
4-5A-1: Privilege To Use Public Ways
4-5A-2: Application For Permit
4-5A-3: Insurance Requirements
4-5A-4: Transfer Of Permit
4-5A-5: Compliance With Provisions; Revocation Of Permit
4-5A-1: PRIVILEGE TO USE PUBLIC WAYS:
The right to use any street or alley of the city for the operation of any
vehicle carrying passengers is hereby declared to be a privilege subject to the
control and regulation of the city council and will not be granted except by
application to said council and a resolution adopted upon said application
granting said right. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000)
4-5A-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
All persons desiring such permits shall file an application therefor in writing
with the city clerk, and said route or routes shall be controlled by the
resolution. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000)
4-5A-3: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
If the city council shall determine to grant a permit, it shall require said
applicant to deposit with the city clerk a policy or policies of insurance
issued by some reliable insurance company or to be approved by the city council
which shall obligate the insurance carrier to pay all damages not to exceed
fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) to any one person and not to exceed one
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for any one accident, to which any
person, whether passenger in said vehicle or not, may become entitled as a
result of personal injuries sustained in the course of operation of such
vehicle, and in addition thereto, to pay any amount not to exceed fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000.00) to any person who may sustain damages to property
as a result of the operation of such vehicle. Said policy shall be for a term
of at least one year, and the permit shall be in effect from date issued
subject to termination at any time that said insurance shall lapse or may not
be renewed, in which case, said permit shall automatically terminate. (Ord.
195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000)
4-5A-4: TRANSFER OF PERMIT:
No such permit shall be transferred without permission of the city council,
granted by resolution, entered of record in the council minutes. (Ord. 195, 2-
21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000)
4-5A-5: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS; REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle along a fixed route
or upon a fixed schedule within the city limits for the purpose of carrying
persons for hire without having complied with all requirements of this article
and resolutions adopted by the city council granting the right to operate
vehicles for hire. In addition to any punishment imposed by the municipal
judge, the city council may, at its own discretion, revoke and terminate such
permit as an additional punishment for such violation. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000,
eff. 3-21-2000; amd. 2006 Code)
ARTICLE B.  TAXICABS
SECTION:
4-5B-1: Intent; Statute Authority
4-5B-2: Definitions
4-5B-3: Liability Under State Tort Act
4-5B-4: Business Licensing Provisions
4-5B-5: Driver's Permit Requirements
4-5B-6: Insurance Requirements
4-5B-7: Vehicle Requirements
4-5B-8: Surrender Of License Or Permit
4-5B-9: Rates And Fares
4-5B-10: Operation Of Taxicab
4-5B-11: Manifests
4-5B-12: Dispatcher
4-5B-1: INTENT; STATUTE AUTHORITY:
It is the intent of this article to regulate the operation and control of
taxicabs within the corporate limits of the city, pursuant to the authority
granted by 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 22-118, and any duly enacted
legislation amendatory or supplementary thereto. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-
21-2000)
4-5B-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
DRIVER: Every person in direct or immediate possession of, in charge of, or
operating a taxicab.
LICENSE: A certificate issued by the city council, authorizing the holder
thereof to conduct a taxicab business in the city.
MAJOR TRAFFIC VIOLATION: Any hazardous moving traffic violation.
MANIFEST: A daily record prepared by the taxicab driver of all trips made by
the driver, showing time, place of origin, destination, number of passengers
and the amount of fares of each trip.
OWNER: Every person, firm, partnership, association or corporation having
proprietary use, ownership or control of any taxicab or fleet of taxicabs.
RATE CARD: A card for display on each taxicab which contains the rates of fare
then in force.
TAXICAB: A motor propelled vehicle which is used for the transportation of
passengers for hire over and along the public streets, not over a defined route
and destination in accordance with and under the direction of the person hiring
such vehicle, for compensation. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000)
4-5B-3: LIABILITY UNDER STATE TORT ACT:
No duty described in this article shall be considered a mandatory duty for the
purpose of the political subdivision tort claims act, 51 Oklahoma Statutes
section 151 et seq. Specifically, the failure of the city to inspect any
taxicab pursuant to this chapter or the negligent inspection of any taxicab by
the city shall not create liability on behalf of the city under the tort claims
act. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000)
4-5B-4: BUSINESS LICENSING PROVISIONS:
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm,
partnership, association or corporation to engage in the business of operating
any taxicab within the city without first obtaining a license from the city
clerk.
   B.   Application For License: Applicants for a license to operate a taxicab
business shall file with the city clerk a verified application which shall set
forth:
      1.   Name, address, business name and any established place of business
of applicant, including address and location of dispatcher.
      2.   The number of vehicles applicant intends to operate as taxicabs.
      3.   The make, type, year of manufacture and passenger seating capacity
of each taxicab for which application for license is made.
      4.   A description of the color scheme, insignia or any other
distinguishing characteristics of the taxicab.
      5.   Proof of financial responsibility as herein described and as
provided by 47 Oklahoma Statutes section 8-104.
      6.   A schedule showing passenger fares to be charged.
   C.   Responsibility For Vehicles: Ownership of all vehicles licensed under
this article shall be at the option of the holder of the license and may be
company owned, leased or independently owned. The license holder shall be
responsible for all vehicles operating under its certificate, and any
violations by an operator of a vehicle, whether leased or independently owned,
shall be deemed a violation by the license holder.
   D.   License Fee: Any person, firm, partnership, association or corporation
which has applied for and received a taxicab license shall, before commencing
the operation of a taxicab company, pay the city clerk a fee of twenty dollars
($20.00) for such license. Said license shall be renewed annually.
   E.   Transfer Of License: No license to operate a taxicab company may be
sold, assigned, mortgaged or otherwise transferred by the person or entity to
whom it is issued.
   F.   Revocation Or Suspension Of License:
      1.   The city may any time, pursuant to the revocation or suspension
proceedings as herein described, revoke or suspend the license granted under
this article, if the city makes any of the following determinations:
         a.   If the owner fails to operate taxicabs in accordance with the
provisions of this article.
         b.   If the owner discontinues or suspends service for a period of ten
(10) days, without first obtaining permission from the city clerk. (Ord. 195,
2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000)
         c.   If the owner refuses to accept a request for service within the
corporate limits of the city for reasons of race, color, religion, national
origin, gender, age or disability. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000; amd.
2006 Code)
         d.   If taxicabs are operated at a rate of fare other than that
specified and on file with the city clerk.
         e.   If the license holder operates, or permits to be operated, any
taxicab for which the required insurance coverage has not been secured and is
not in full force and effect. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000)
      2.   The city clerk shall initiate revocation or suspension proceeding by
giving written notice to such owner that a public hearing will be held by a
taxicab commission consisting of the city manager, the city clerk, and the
chief of police. Such notice shall be given at least five (5) days prior to the
date of such hearing and shall specify the grounds for revocation or
suspension. The taxicab commission shall consider all relevant testimony before
making its determination thereon. An owner may appeal from an adverse ruling by
the panel to the city council whose decision shall be final. (Ord. 195, 2-21-
2000, eff. 3-21-2000; amd. 2006 Code)
4-5B-5: DRIVER'S PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or
drive a taxicab which originates trips within the city without first obtaining
a permit to do so from the city clerk.
   B.   Application And Fee: To secure such permission, a prospective taxicab
driver shall file a written application with the city clerk. Application shall
be accompanied by a nonrefundable processing fee in the amount of ten dollars
($10.00). Any person may apply to the city for a permit to operate a taxicab by
filing with the city clerk, upon forms supplied by the city, an application
containing the following information:
      1.   Name (including all aliases or previously used names), address and
date of birth of applicant.
      2.   Whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a felony and the
date of such conviction.
      3.   Whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a misdemeanor
within five (5) years prior to the application.
      4.   The endorsement of the owner certifying the applicant who is to be
employed as a driver.
      5.   Number, class and expiration date of the state of Oklahoma driver's
license of all prospective drivers.
      6.   Whether a driver's license issued to the applicant by any state or
agency has ever been revoked and the reason for such revocation. (Ord. 195, 2-
21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000)
      7.   Such other information regarding the health and experience of the
applicant as may be necessary or desirable to enable the city clerk to
determine the applicant's qualification for a taxicab driver's permit.
   C.   Approval Or Denial Of Permit:
      1.   Upon receipt of an application for a driver's permit, the city clerk
shall conduct an investigation of the applicant, with the assistance of the
chief of police, and on the basis of such investigation, shall either approve
or deny the application. No permit shall be issued to any of the following
persons: (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000; amd. 2006 Code)
         a.   Any person under the age of twenty one (21) years.
         b.   Any person convicted of a felony or misdemeanor offense which
reasonably and directly indicates a potential risk to the general public. This
restriction shall apply to misdemeanor convictions occurring within five (5)
years of the date of the application.
         c.   Any person convicted of leaving the scene of an accident,
reckless driving or driving in actual physical control of a vehicle while under
the influence of intoxicating liquor and/or any drug within six (6) months of
the date of the application, or upon conviction of any two (2) or more of these
offenses within five (5) years of the date of the application. However, no
permit shall be issued to any person convicted of any offense described herein
if such person was driving a motor vehicle for hire at the time the offense was
committed.
         d.   Any person not possessing a valid state of Oklahoma driver's
license of the class required by state law for the operation of taxicabs.
      2.   The restrictions in this subsection shall apply both to persons
possessing a driver's permit and to person seeking renewal of such permit.
(Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000)
   D.   Issuance Of Permit: Nontransferability; Permit Posted:
      1.   A permit shall be issued by the city clerk to the applicant.
      2.   Said permit shall not be transferable.
      3.   Each taxicab shall have located in the driver's compartment and in
view of the passengers therein a copy of the "permit to operate" issued to such
taxicab driver.
   E.   Contents Of Permit; Validity And Termination:
      1.   The permit shall bear the name and photograph of the applicant, date
of expiration of the permit and the name of the owner for which the driver is
authorized to operate the vehicle. Such permit shall be delivered to the driver
named therein and shall be valid only so long as said driver continues in the
employ of such license holder.
      2.   Upon the termination of any driver's employment, the owner by whom
such driver has been employed shall immediately give the city clerk written
notice of such termination and the reasons therefor.
   F.   Renewal Of Permits: The applicant shall be required to meet the same
standards as set forth in this article for initial permit. No refund shall be
made for any reason, and no permit fee shall be prorated.
   G.   Revocation Or Suspension Of Permit; Report Of Violations:
      1.   Any person issued a driver's permit who subsequently is convicted of
any felony or misdemeanor offense or who ceases to possess a valid state of
Oklahoma commercial driver's license of the class required by state law for the
operation of taxicabs shall immediately so inform his employer and the city
clerk.
      2.   The city clerk shall revoke the driver's permit of any driver who
ceases to possess a valid driver's license or is convicted of a felony or
misdemeanor when such conviction results in the driver being unable to drive a
taxicab, or the city clerk determines that such conviction reasonably and
directly indicates a potential risk to the public.
      3.   The city clerk may revoke or suspend any driver's permit if the
driver's state of Oklahoma department of public safety record includes three
(3) or more moving violations within the preceding twelve (12) month period, or
if the city clerk determines the driver is a danger to public safety.
   H.   Notice Of Intent To Deny Or Revoke Permit; Hearing:
      1.   Whenever the city clerk intends to deny an application or revoke a
permit for driving a taxicab, he shall give the applicant or permit holder
written notice of intent to deny or revoke such driver's permit, stating
grounds upon which denial or revocation is contemplated and shall inform such
applicant or permit holder that he/she has ten (10) days to file a written
request for a hearing. The application may be denied or the permit revoked if a
request for hearing is not received within a ten (10) day period.
      2.   If the applicant or permit holder files a timely request for a
hearing, the city clerk shall set a time and place for the hearing and shall
consider all relevant evidence and testimony prior to making a decision
thereon. The decision of the city clerk to revoke a permit or deny an
application may be appealed to the city council. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-
21-2000; amd. 2006 Code)
4-5B-6: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
It shall be unlawful for an owner or driver to operate a taxicab within the
corporate limits of the city unless such owner or driver shall first have filed
with the city clerk proof of financial responsibility as defined in 47 Oklahoma
Statutes section 8-104, and any duly enacted amendment thereto, with limits as
defined in section
4-5A-3 of this title. If at any time the policy of insurance is cancelled by
the company issuing the same, or the authority of the company to do business in
the state shall be revoked, the city clerk shall replace such policy with
another policy satisfactory to the city attorney, and in default thereof, the
owner's authority to operate a taxicab shall be revoked. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000,
eff. 3-21-2000; amd. 2006 Code)
4-5B-7: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Initial Inspection; Compliance With Rules And Regulations: Prior to the
use and operation of any vehicle under the provisions of this article, the
vehicle shall be thoroughly inspected by the Lone Grove police department in
accordance with the rules and regulations prescribed by this section.
   B.   Periodic Inspections: Every vehicle operating under this section shall
be periodically inspected by the police department at such intervals as shall
be established by the chief of police to ensure the continued maintenance of
safe operating conditions. If, upon inspection, it is found that the vehicle
operating under this article does not meet the requirements established herein,
the chief of police shall cause the vehicle license to be suspended, until such
a time as the vehicle has been made to comply with the rules herein.
   C.   Cleanliness And Condition: Every vehicle under this article shall be
kept clean and the upholstery in good repair.
   D.   Standard Equipment: All vehicles to be licensed and used as a taxicab
shall have as standard equipment:
      1.   Four (4) wheel brakes in good operating condition.
      2.   Parking brake in good operating condition.
      3.   Front and rear bumpers.
      4.   Heater, defroster and air conditioner.
      5.   Right and left side and rearview mirror.
      6.   Speedometer exposed to view and in good operating condition.
      7.   Windshield wipers.
      8.   Tires with a minimum of 2/32 inch tread.
      9.   Factory recommended shock absorbers.
      10.   Properly operating turn indicators.
      11.   All glass shall be safety glazed glass equal to manufacturer's
standard specification with no cracks or damage.
   E.   Maintenance Requirements: It shall be the responsibility of the owner
to ensure that every taxicab operating under his license is in safe working
order and meets the requirements of the state vehicle code.
   F.   Identification On Vehicle: Every taxicab operated in the city shall
bear the following identification: the owner's name, monogram or insignia
approved pursuant to the license, together with the taxicab identification
number and the owner's telephone number. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000)
4-5B-8: SURRENDER OF LICENSE OR PERMIT:
All permits or licenses which shall have been suspended or revoked by the city
clerk or by the city council shall be surrendered to the city clerk, and the
operation of all taxicabs covered by such permits or licenses shall cease and
be unlawful. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000; amd. 2006 Code)
4-5B-9: RATES AND FARES:
   A.   Filed With Clerk: The rate schedule specifying the rates and charges
established for operation of a taxi service shall be filed by the owner or
operator of such service with the city clerk. No rates or charges other than
those specified in such rate schedule shall be made by the owner or operator.
The owner or operator shall file a notice of any rate adjustments at least
thirty (30) days prior to the effective dates of any rate change or adjustment
with the city clerk, setting forth the rates or changes then in effect and the
proposed rates or changes and the date they are to take effect.
   B.   Published In Newspaper: In addition to filing notice with the city
clerk, the owner or operator shall cause notice of such proposed rate increase
to be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city
at least thirty (30) days prior to the effective date.
   C.   Posted In Taxicab: Rates and charges shall be posted in each taxicab in
a place visible to passengers. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any
taxicab or public transportation vehicle in the city to charge or collect for
transportation services at a rate more or less than that specified in the rate
schedule on file with the city clerk. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000)
4-5B-10: OPERATION OF TAXICAB:
   A.   Most Direct Route Required: Any driver employed to transport passengers
to a definite point shall take the most direct route that will take the
passengers to their destination safely and expeditiously.
   B.   Receipt On Request: If requested, every driver of a taxicab shall give
a receipt upon payment of a correct fare. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000)
   C.   Refusal Of Service: It shall be unlawful for any driver to refuse, when
his vehicle is in service and not otherwise engaged, to transport any person
who requests such service because of race, color, religion, national origin,
gender, age or disability. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000; amd. 2006
Code)
   D.   Additional Passengers: It shall be unlawful for any driver to permit
any other person to occupy or ride in a taxicab, unless the first person
employing the taxicab shall consent to the acceptance of additional passengers.
   E.   Seating Capacity Not To Be Exceeded; Children: No driver shall permit
more passengers to be carried in a taxicab than the rated seating capacity of
such taxicab as the statement issued for such taxicab reflects. A child shall
not be carried in the arms of another passenger. The child shall be transported
in compliance with state law. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000)
4-5B-11: MANIFESTS:
   A.   Every taxicab driver shall maintain a daily manifest upon which is
recorded all trips made each day, showing time and place of origin and
destination of the trip and amount of fare. All completed manifests shall be
returned to the owner at the conclusion of his tour of duty. The forms for each
manifest shall be furnished to the driver by the owner and shall be of a
character approved by the city clerk.
   B.   Every holder of a license to operate a taxicab company shall maintain
all taxicab manifests in a safe place for one year, and such manifests shall be
available to the city clerk upon request. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000;
amd. 2006 Code)
4-5B-12: DISPATCHER:
   A.   Each owner shall provide and maintain a dispatcher to receive calls for
service. All requests for service inside the corporate limits shall be answered
as soon as practicable.
   B.   Notice of change of business or dispatch address or telephone number
shall be provided to the city clerk at least seventy two (72) hours prior to
such change. (Ord. 195, 2-21-2000, eff. 3-21-2000; amd. 2006 Code)
CHAPTER 6
OIL AND GAS DRILLING
SECTION:
4-6-0: Definition
4-6-1: Compliance With Provisions
4-6-2: Minimum Standards
4-6-3: Oil Or Gas District Created
4-6-4: Required Information
4-6-5: Permit Required
4-6-6: Permit Fee And Issuance
4-6-7: Bond Requirements
4-6-8: Well Location Restrictions
4-6-9: Enforcement
4-6-10: Penalty
4-6-0: DEFINITION:
An "oil or gas well" is defined as any single vertical well bore is a well and
a single horizontal well bore is a well, i.e., one vertical well bore and four
(4) horizontal well bores are equal to five (5) oil or gas wells. Further, a
well is defined as one that is drilled inside the city limits of the city of
Lone Grove or extends into the city limits of the city of Lone Grove is
considered to be an oil or gas well. (Ord. 2013-249, 5-23-2013, eff. 6-23-2013)
4-6-1: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
   A.   No person, firm, partnership, corporation, or entity shall engage in
any work or erect any structure, tanks, machinery, pipelines, or other
appurtenances incident to the drilling for or production of petroleum or
natural gas, or operate, maintain, or permit any equipment, structures or
appurtenances incident to such production to exist, or use or maintain any
property or premises in violation of any of the terms of this chapter. (1990
Code § 5-401)
   B.   Within the corporate limits of the city, hereinafter designated as the
oil or gas district, uses of buildings and premises for petroleum wells,
natural gas wells, derricks, machinery boilers, tool houses, storage tanks, and
all other appurtenances necessary for the mining, drilling and production of
crude petroleum and natural gas are permitted after compliance with all
requirements of this chapter and the laws, regulations and rules of the state.
(1990 Code § 5-407)
4-6-2: MINIMUM STANDARDS:
Any person or entity drilling, operating, or maintaining an oil or gas well
shall use all necessary care, and take all precautions of whatsoever nature
which shall be reasonably necessary under the circumstances to protect the
general public. The provisions of this chapter shall be deemed to be the
minimum requirements for the preservation of the public peace, health and
safety, and compliance with all terms thereof shall not be deemed to relieve
any person from any additional duty imposed by law. (1990 Code § 5-402)
4-6-3: OIL OR GAS DISTRICT CREATED:
There is hereby created an oil or gas district in the city in which no
buildings, structures, or premises shall be used, and no building or structures
shall be erected, moved, altered, or repaired, which are arranged, designed, or
intended to be used for any purpose other than a use permitted under the
regulations of the district within which such property is situated as
authorized by this chapter. (1990 Code § 5-406)
4-6-4: REQUIRED INFORMATION:
The superintendent or any other person in charge of the oil or gas lease in
question shall furnish accurate information concerning all drilling operations,
depths of wells, character of equipment, or any other information which may be
required for the proper inspection or regulation of all wells, equipment or
appurtenances thereto, to the chief of the fire or police department or any
authorized representatives. (1990 Code § 5-405)
4-6-5: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall open a well drilled for the production of petroleum or natural
gas or permit to flow therefrom any petroleum or natural gas, or engage in any
work or erect any structures, tanks, machinery, pipelines, or other
appurtenances incident to the production of petroleum or natural gas unless a
permit for the drilling and operation of the well shall have first been
obtained as provided by the terms of this chapter. (1990 Code § 5-408)
4-6-6: PERMIT FEE AND ISSUANCE:
The fee for a permit for the drilling or putting down of each well for the
purpose of producing oil or gas within the corporate limits of the city shall
be five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) per each oil and/or gas well. The permit
shall be issued to any person upon full payment of the fee to the city
treasurer. (1990 Code § 5-409; amd. 2006 Code; Ord. 2013-249, 5-23-2013, eff.
6-23-2013)
4-6-7: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
An applicant for a permit to drill an oil or gas well shall file with the city
clerk a bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) conditioned that
the person shall carry public liability and property damage insurance covering
the drilling operations in question in an amount not less than five hundred
thousand dollars ($500,000.00). This provision shall in no manner affect any
other requirement or regulation now made for drilling and operating oil and gas
wells. (1990 Code § 5-410; amd. 2006 Code)
4-6-8: WELL LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
No oil and/or natural gas well shall be drilled nearer than fifty feet (50')
from the property line of the tract where the well is situated. No oil and/or
natural gas well shall be drilled nearer than one thousand feet (1,000') from
any residential dwelling or structure where humans reside, or commercial
building. (Ord. 169, 5-18-1998)
4-6-9: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Fire, Police Chiefs: The chief of the city fire department and the city
police chief shall enforce the provisions of this chapter and shall have full
police authority. (1990 Code § 5-403)
   B.   Additional Enforcement Personnel: The city manager is authorized to
appoint additional persons or to designate additional city employees to assist
in the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. (1990 Code § 5-404)
4-6-10: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, partnership, corporation, or entity who violates the terms
and provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of an offense and shall
be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1990 Code § 5-412)
CHAPTER 7
ADULT ORIENTED BUSINESSES
SECTION:
4-7-1: Purpose
4-7-2: Scope
4-7-3: Definitions
4-7-4: Application Of Chapter
4-7-5: Business Application Required
4-7-6: Business Application For Adult Use Facility Or Sexually Oriented
Business
4-7-7: Complete Application Includes Payment Of Fees
4-7-8: Locations Of Adult Uses And/Or Sexually Oriented Businesses
4-7-9: Conditions Of Operation
4-7-10: Signs
4-7-11: Enforcement
4-7-12: Violations
4-7-13: Exclusion
4-7-1: PURPOSE:
The city council of Lone Grove, Oklahoma, ordains the purpose of this chapter
is to regulate all adult or sexually oriented businesses as identified herein
in order to protect the health, safety, general welfare and property values of
the citizens of Lone Grove through reasonable and uniform regulation of said
businesses throughout the municipality. (Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-
2006)
4-7-2: SCOPE:
This chapter shall apply to all businesses in the city of Lone Grove whose
primary or secondary purpose is to sell, distribute or display adult oriented
materials through wholesale, retail or other distribution means or who provide
adult oriented or sexually explicit entertainment, education or other means of
similar communication. (Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006)
4-7-3: DEFINITIONS:
The definitions defined below have the meanings given them. All other words
and/or phrases for which a definition is not provided shall be assumed to
retain its common usage as found in a published dictionary.
ADULT USES: Adult bookstores, stores that rent or sell "adult" magazines, VHS
tapes, DVDs, adult hotels and motels, adult motion picture theaters, adult
mini-motion picture theaters, adult massage parlors, adult health/sports clubs,
adult sauna/steam room/bathhouses, tattoo parlors or establishments where
tattoos and body piercing services are offered, adult companionship
establishments, businesses that offer adult or sexually explicit "toys" or
devices that are designed for sexual gratification or entertainment, adult
novelty businesses, strip clubs, adult car washes, adult motion picture arcade,
panorama booths, adult peepshow booths, adult modeling studios and other
premises, enterprises or establishments, businesses, or places open to some or
all members of the public at or in which there is an emphasis on the
presentation or display, depiction or description of specified sexual
activities or specified anatomical areas which the public could see or observe.
These types of businesses shall further be defined as "adult uses" or "sexually
oriented businesses". This definition does not apply to the practice of
medicine, surgery, osteopathy, chiropractic, physical therapy or podiatry by
Oklahoma licensed or registered persons.
CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER: The person appointed or employed by the city manager
to administer this chapter within the limits of Lone Grove. (Ord. 2006-217, 8-
3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006)
4-7-4: APPLICATION OF CHAPTER:
No structure shall be erected, converted, or altered in any manner, nor
existing land use be converted for the purpose of engaging in adult uses or
sexually oriented businesses as identified in this chapter except as permitted
by this chapter. All adult uses shall be in conformity with this chapter and
the laws of the state of Oklahoma as they apply to sexually oriented
businesses. (Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006)
4-7-5: BUSINESS APPLICATION REQUIRED:
All businesses engaging in "adult uses" or sexually oriented businesses as
defined in this chapter shall require a business application from the city of
Lone Grove, as defined and administered, that shall be granted only after a
public hearing on the application. An application form provided by the city
clerk shall be completed and fees paid before any public hearing will be
scheduled. (Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006; amd. Ord. 2007-221, 1-16-
2007, eff. 1-16-2007)
4-7-6: BUSINESS APPLICATION FOR ADULT USE FACILITY OR SEXUALLY ORIENTED
BUSINESS:
An application for an adult use facility or sexually oriented business shall be
made on a form provided by the city clerk and approved by the city council.
This application shall include:
   A.   A detailed statement of all activities and types of business to be
conducted on the premises. The statement shall be in sufficient detail to
determine the extent to which said business fits the definitions of "adult
uses" or a sexually oriented business.
   B.   The address and legal description of the land or property on which the
adult use or sexually oriented business shall conduct business.
   C.   A building plan, drawn to scale, of the premises to be built, leased,
or renovated. Said building plan shall include existing configuration and final
configuration of floor plans.
   D.   Intended days and hours of operation.
   E.   Provisions made to restrict access by minors.
   F.   Provisions made to provide security for employees and patrons. (Ord.
2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006)
   G.   A signature to a statement attesting to the fact that any withholding
of facts or information or the providing of false information through the
course of the application and investigation process and subsequent operation of
the business shall be grounds for denial or revocation of the business
application. (Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006; amd. Ord. 2007-221, 1-16-
2007, eff. 1-16-2007)
   H.   The full name, street address, city, state and zip code of the
applicant or applicants, and if a corporation, partnership or fictitious
business entity, then the full names and current street addresses of all
owners, partners, or persons who hold any type of equity ownership position or
managing authority in the company. (Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006)
4-7-7: COMPLETE APPLICATION INCLUDES PAYMENT OF FEES:
The application referred to in section
4-7-6 of this chapter shall not be complete until the appropriate fees
established by the city council of Lone Grove have been paid in full. (Ord.
2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006)
4-7-8: LOCATIONS OF ADULT USES AND/OR SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES:
No adult uses, sexually oriented businesses, tattoo and/or body piercing
businesses shall be located at any time in any residential or agricultural zone
of the city of Lone Grove. The city council shall permit "adult uses" as
defined in this chapter to be permitted with a business application only in the
light industrial zoned area (I-1) of the municipality designated by the city
council, subject to the following conditions: (Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-
3-2006; amd. Ord. 2007-221, 1-16-2007, eff. 1-16-2007)
   A.   No adult use or sexually oriented business shall be located closer than
one thousand feet (1,000') from another adult use facility within the
municipality.
   B.   No adult use facility/business shall be located closer than one
thousand feet (1,000') from any place of worship or religious institution,
hospital, school, daycare, public park, public library or other public
institution. Measurements to determine location shall be made in a straight
horizontal line from the actual building in which the facility/business is
located to the nearest aforementioned property boundary.
   C.   No adult use or sexually oriented business or facility shall be located
closer than one thousand feet (1,000') from any residential lot line,
residential zoning district or zone, or residential planned unit development.
Measurements to determine location shall be made in a straight horizontal line
from the actual building in which the facility is located to the nearest
property line of said zones or residences.
   D.   No adult use or sexually oriented business as defined in this chapter
shall be located closer than five hundred feet (500') from any other business
or establishment selling intoxicating beverages, either on-sale or off-sale.
   E.   There shall be only one adult use or sexually oriented business as
defined in this chapter located in any building, facility, establishment or
place of business. (Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006)
4-7-9: CONDITIONS OF OPERATION:
   A.   All adult use or sexually oriented businesses shall be confined to the
interior of the building. All business shall be conducted in a manner that
eliminates the possibility of observation by the general public either through
casual observation while driving past or by viewing through the windows.
   B.   All adult use facilities/sexually oriented businesses shall not sell
nonintoxicating beverages or imitation liquors at any time. Said businesses
also shall not sell wines, beer or intoxicating beverages. Further, said
businesses shall not allow the consumption of said beverages on the premises,
including all portions of the property parcel.
   C.   All adult uses/sexually oriented businesses shall prominently display a
sign at the entrance to the business within two feet (2') of the door that
clearly states the following words: "THIS ESTABLISHMENT SELLS OR DISPLAYS
MATERIAL CONTAINING ADULT THEMES. PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN (18) YEARS OF AGE
SHALL NOT ENTER." Signs at adult use or sexually oriented businesses may not
advertise a "cover fee" or "charge" that shall be credited toward a purchase at
any location on the exterior of the building.
   D.   All adult use or sexually oriented businesses shall prominently display
their hours of operation. Said businesses shall not operate between the hours
of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and twelve o'clock (12:00) noon Monday
through Saturday. All said businesses shall not be open or sell products on
Sunday, which starts at one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. Central
Standard Time. (Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006)
   E.   All conditions listed above and any other conditions deemed necessary
by the city council of Lone Grove shall be clearly stated as conditions on the
business application when granted.
   F.   Persons with prior misdemeanor or felony convictions concerning
sexually related offenses or assault behavior shall not be granted a business
application for an adult facility. This prohibition shall apply to any person
listed on the business application, or listed as an owner or officer of any
entity so applying. (Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006; amd. Ord. 2007-
221, 1-16-2007, eff. 1-16-2007)
4-7-10: SIGNS:
   A.   All signs for adult use or sexually oriented businesses shall be
affixed to the building in which the adult use or sexually oriented business is
conducted. Freestanding signs and roof mounted signs shall not be allowed.
Further, there shall be no directional signs allowed within the corporate
limits of Lone Grove. Any proposed sign for adult use or sexually oriented
businesses shall be approved by the code enforcement officer of Lone Grove
prior to installation.
   B.   Signs shall not contain any flashing lights, electronic or mechanical
message boards, sexually explicit images, or moving elements.
   C.   Merchandise, photos, caricatures or pictures of the products or
entertainment on the premises shall not be displayed either on the sign or in
the windows or other areas where they may be viewed from the public rights of
way or adjoining properties. Further, "sandwich style" signs shall not be
utilized at adult use or sexually oriented businesses. (Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-
2006, eff. 8-3-2006)
4-7-11: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   It is the responsibility of the city of Lone Grove's mayor and council
members to enforce and administer this chapter. Penal violations shall be
enforced by the city police department. The city council may appoint a code
enforcement officer or administrator, delegate the oversight to the city
planning commission, or divide the enforcement work among the departments of
the city, including, but not limited to, the Lone Grove police department.
(Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006)
   B.   Change of ownership of the adult use or sexually oriented business
shall require a new business application with all of the process and
investigation being completed prior to opening for business. Continuing to
operate the business after change of ownership, without filing of a new
business application, shall be a violation of this chapter and grounds for
revocation of the existing permit. (Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006;
amd. Ord. 2007-221, 1-16-2007, eff. 1-16-2007)
   C.   All decisions of the Lone Grove code enforcement officer shall be
subject to appeal. An appeal of a decision made by said official may be
initiated by the applicant within ten (10) days from the date of an adverse
decision by the code enforcement officer by filing a written notice specifying
the grounds for the appeal, and delivering same to the city clerk. The appeal
shall be heard by the Lone Grove planning and zoning commission at its next
regularly scheduled meeting. An appeal may be initiated by the applicant within
ten (10) days from the date of an adverse decision by the planning and zoning
commission by filing a written notice specifying the grounds for the appeal and
delivering same to the city clerk. The appeal shall be heard by the city
council at its next regularly scheduled meeting or at a special meeting set by
the mayor. The city council's decision to affirm, reverse, or modify the
decision of the planning and zoning commission shall be final. At any hearing
provided herein, the applicant shall be allowed to appear in person and by
counsel, and shall have the right to cross examine any witness who testifies.
(Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006)
4-7-12: VIOLATIONS:
Any person, firm, corporation, partnership or entity who violates, neglects,
refuses to comply with or assists or participates in any way or manner in the
violation of any of the provisions or requirements of this chapter or condition
of a business application granted in accordance with this chapter, shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor. Said violator is subject to the maximum penalty
prescribed by Lone Grove penal ordinances and/or the city charter. Each day
such violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense.
   A.   Upon notice by the Lone Grove code enforcement officer or an authorized
representative of the city, that a violation has occurred not rising to a penal
offense, the owner of an adult use or sexually oriented business shall have ten
(10) days to bring the violation into compliance with this chapter and any
other ordinance cited in the violation notice. Failure to comply shall result
in immediate revocation of the business application by the code enforcement
officer.
   B.   No person who has been convicted of any sex related offense, regardless
whether said offense was a misdemeanor or felony under the laws of any state,
or who is registered as a sex offender with any state, municipal or federal law
enforcement agency, shall be eligible to file for a business application under
this chapter. (Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006; amd. Ord. 2007-221, 1-
16-2007, eff. 1-16-2007)
   C.   In the event of a violation of this chapter, any costs of enforcement,
including administrative and legal expenses incurred in the enforcement
proceedings may be assessed against the party found to have violated this
chapter. Within forty five (45) days after the conclusion of a civil or
criminal case, the clerk of the Lone Grove municipal court may certify the
costs of enforcement for assessment against a violator's property where the
violator has either been found to have violated this chapter by the municipal
court or has admitted the violation. The reasonable costs of enforcement shall
be transmitted to the Carter County assessor for purpose of assessing the
transmitted costs to the ad valorem tax rolls of the violator. (Ord. 2006-217,
8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-2006)
4-7-13: EXCLUSION:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any theatrical production
performed in a theater, by a professional or amateur theatrical or musical
company, which has serious artistic merit. (Ord. 2006-217, 8-3-2006, eff. 8-3-
2006)

4-8-1: IN GENERAL:
4-8-1-1: LEGISLATIVE INTENT AND PURPOSE:
   A.   Intent And Purpose:
      1.   The intent of this chapter is to ensure the health and safety of the
citizens and visitors to the City of Lone Grove and provide reasonable and
orderly regulation of medical marijuana as authorized by the lawful passage of
Oklahoma State Question 788 in 2018. Only the powers enumerated under this
chapter shall be proper. Any power not specifically enumerated is prohibited.
         a.   Any person, persons, or entity violating any provisions of this
chapter, either by doing anything which is prohibited or by failing to do
anything which is commanded, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon
conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount not to exceed five hundred
dollars ($500.00) plus court costs. Each separate violation of this chapter
shall constitute a separate offense. Where a lesser fine is mandated by State
law, the lesser amount of fine shall be applicable.
         b.   The regulations are intended to apply to all medical marijuana
for personal use or any medical marijuana business permitted under State
Question 788. The code is intended to provide regulations to provide guidance
to those persons and to regulate the impact that medical marijuana cultivation
and production will have on health, safety, and community resources.
         c.   Regulations for the use of medical marijuana are necessary to
address the impact of medical marijuana on the City.
         d.   Nothing in this chapter is intended to promote or condone the
production, distribution, or possession of marijuana in violation of any
applicable State law.
         e.   Operation of a medical marijuana business is a revocable
privilege and not a property right.
         f.   Medical marijuana being a heavily regulated industry in the State
of Oklahoma and the City of Lone Grove, all holders of permits are assumed to
be fully aware of the law. The City shall therefore not be required to issue
warnings before issuing citations for violations of this chapter.
      2.   In addition to the purpose outlined above, this chapter is intended
to protect the public health, safety, and welfare of the residents and patients
of the City by prescribing the manner in which medical marijuana businesses can
be conducted in the City and the manner in which medical marijuana can be
cultivated by permittees. Further, the purpose of the chapter is to:
         a.   Provide for a means of cultivation, production, and distribution
of marijuana to patients who qualify to obtain, possess, and use marijuana for
medical purposes as authorized by State law.
         b.   Protect public health and safety through reasonable limitations
on business operations as they relate to noise, air, and water quality, food
safety, neighborhood and patient safety, security for the business and its
personnel, fire safety, and other health and safety concerns.
         c.   Establish fees to cover the cost to the City of permitting
medical marijuana businesses in an amount sufficient for the City to recover
its costs of the permitting program.
         d.   Adopt a mechanism for monitoring compliance with the provisions
of this chapter.
         e.   Create regulations that address the particular needs of the
patients and residents of the City and coordinate with laws that may be enacted
by the State regarding the issue.
         f.   Facilitate the implementation of State Question 788 without going
beyond the authority granted by it.
         g.   Issue medical marijuana business permits to those individuals and
entities who are legally qualified and have demonstrated an intent and ability
to comply with this chapter. (Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
4-8-1-2: MEDICAL MARIJUANA CONTROL PROGRAM ADOPTED:
   A.   Oklahoma State Department of Health Regulations, title 310, chapter
681, Medical Marijuana Program as it may from time to time be amended is
adopted by reference and is made part of the ordinances of this City, as if
fully set forth in this Code. The provisions of these regulations shall take
effect and be controlling with the City limits so that a violation of the
provisions of the regulations shall also constitute a violation of this Code.
Nothing in this section shall grant to the City the power or jurisdiction to
prosecute offenses that a City is not authorized to prosecute.
   B.   Any crimes specified in the rules or other laws as felonies are
specifically excluded from inclusion in this chapter.
   C.   Unless stated otherwise, the penalty for a misdemeanor violation of the
rules as adopted by this chapter shall be the maximum penalty allowed by State
law but not exceeding the jurisdictional limits of the Lone Grove Municipal
Court. (Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
4-8-1-3: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and terms, when used in this chapter, shall have the
following meaning, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise:
APPLICANT: Means the natural person in whose name a permit would be issued.
COMPLETE APPLICATION: Means a document prepared in accordance with the rules
and forms and instructions provided by the City of Lone Grove, including any
supporting documentation required as well as the application fee.
DISPENSARY: Means an entity licensed by the Oklahoma State Health Department
pursuant to title 63 Oklahoma Statutes section 421A and permitted by the City
of Lone Grove pursuant to this chapter, which allows the entity to purchase
medical marijuana from a processor permittee or grower permittee and sell
medical marijuana only to qualified patients and caregivers.
DISPENSE: Means the selling of medical marijuana or a medical marijuana product
to a qualified patient or the patient's designated caregiver that is packaged
in a suitable container appropriately labeled for subsequent administration to
or use by a qualified patient.
DOMICILE: Means a person's true, fixed, primary permanent home and place of
habitation and the tax parcel on which it is located. It is the place where the
person intends to remain and to which the person expects to return when the
person leaves without intending to establish a new domicile elsewhere.
ENTITY: Means an individual, a general partnership, a limited partnership, a
limited liability company, a trust, an estate, an association, a corporation,
or any other legal or commercial entity.
GROWER OR COMMERCIAL GROWER: Means an entity that has been licensed by the
Oklahoma State Department of Health and permitted by the City of Lone Grove,
which allows the entity to grow, harvest, and package medical marijuana to a
dispensary, processor, or researcher.
MANUFACTURE: Means the process of converting harvested plant material into
medical marijuana concentrate by physical or chemical means for use as an
ingredient in a medical marijuana project.
MARIJUANA: Means all parts of a plant from the genus cannabis, whether growing
or not; the seeds of a plant of that type; the resin extracted from a part of a
plant of that type; and every compound, manufacture, sale, derivative, mixture,
or preparation of a plant of that type or of its seeds or resin. "Marijuana"
does not include the mature stalks of the plant, fiber produced from the
stalks, oils or cake made from the seeds of the plant, or any other compound,
manufacture, sale derivative, mixture, or preparation of the mature stalks,
except the resin extracted from the mature stalks, fiber, oil or cake, or the
sterilized seed of the plant that is incapable of germination.
MATURE PLANT: Means a harvestable female marijuana plant that is flowering.
Mature plants are not authorized under this section
4-8-1 prior to sixty (60) days after the enactment of 63 Oklahoma Statutes
section 420A, et seq.
MEDICAL MARIJUANA: Means marijuana which is grown, processed, dispensed,
tested, possessed, or used for a medical purpose.
MEDICAL MARIJUANA BUSINESS: Means any business licensed by the Oklahoma State
Health Department and permitted by the City of Lone Grove to dispense, grow,
research, or process medical marijuana.
MEDICAL MARIJUANA CONCENTRATE (CONCENTRATE): Means a substance obtained by
separation cannabinoids from any part of the marijuana plant by physical or
chemical means, so as to deliver a product with a cannabinoid concentration
greater than the raw plant material from which it is derived, intended to be
refined for use as an ingredient in a medical marijuana product and not for
administration to a qualified patient.
MEDICAL MARIJUANA PRODUCT: Means a product which contains cannabinoids that
have been extracted from plant material or the resin therefrom by physical or
chemical means and is intended for administration to a qualified patient,
including but not limited to oils, tinctures, edibles, pills, topical forms,
gels, creams, forms medically appropriate for administration by vaporization or
nebulizer, patches, and liquids excluding live plant forms.
MEDICAL MARIJUANA WASTE: Means unused, surplus, returned or out- of-date
marijuana; recalled marijuana; unused marijuana; plant debris of the plant of
the genus cannabis, including dead plants and all unused plant parts and roots;
and any wastewater generated during growing and processing.
PERMITTEE: Means any natural born person or entity that holds a marijuana
permit provided for in this chapter.
PRIVATE SCHOOL: Means an elementary, middle, or high school maintained by
private individuals, religious organizations, or corporations, funded at least
in part, by fees or tuition.
PROCESSOR: Means an entity that has been licensed by the Oklahoma State
Department of Health and permitted by the City of Lone Grove, which allows the
entity to: purchase marijuana from a commercial grower; prepare, manufacture,
package, sell to and deliver medical marijuana products to a dispensary
permittee or other processor permittee; and may process marijuana received from
a qualified patient into a medical marijuana concentrate, for a fee.
PUBLIC SCHOOL: Means an elementary, middle, or high school established under
State law, regulated by the local State authorities in the various political
subdivisions, funded and maintained by public taxation, and open and free to
all children of the particular district where the school is located.
RETAILER: As used in title 63 Oklahoma Statutes section 421A et seq., means a
dispensary.
REVOCATION: Means the City of Lone Grove's final decision that any permit
issued pursuant to this chapter is rescinded because the individual or entity
does not comply with the applicable requirements contained in this chapter.
SCHOOL: Means either public or private nurseries, kindergartens, elementary,
secondary schools and technology center schools, night schools, adult and other
special classes, vocational and technical instruction and such other school
classes and instruction as may be authorized by law.
SEEDLING: Means an immature marijuana plant that has no flowers.
STATE QUESTION: Means Oklahoma State Question 788 and Initiative Petition
Number 412. (Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
4-8-2: COMMERCIAL MEDICAL MARIJUANA BUSINESS PERMIT:
4-8-2-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, persons, or other business entity to
operate as a commercial medical marijuana dispensary, commercial medical
marijuana grower, commercial medical marijuana manufacturer, or commercial
medical marijuana processor within the corporate limits of the City of Lone
Grove without having first obtained a permit therefor as provided herein. The
fees for the permits required hereunder shall be established by ordinance of
the Board of Commissioners of the City of Lone Grove. (Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-
2018)
4-8-2-2: ADDITIONAL LICENSES AND PERMITS MAY BE REQUIRED:
The permit requirement set forth in this chapter shall be in addition to, and
not in lieu of, any other licensing and permitting requirements imposed by any
other Federal, State, or local law, including, by way of example, any
applicable building permit. (Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
4-8-2-3: PERMIT DOES NOT PROVIDE ANY EXCEPTION, DEFENSE, OR IMMUNITY FROM OTHER
LAWS:
The issuance of any permit pursuant to this chapter does not create an
exception, defense, or immunity to any person or entity in regard to any
potential criminal liability the person or entity may have for the production,
distribution, or possession of marijuana, nor does it create an exception,
defense, or immunity from any other legal violation. (Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-
2018)
4-8-2-4: SEPARATE PERMIT REQUIRED FOR EACH LOCATION:
A separate permit shall be required for each premises from which a commercial
medical marijuana business is operated. Except as specifically provided in this
chapter, no two (2) or more different commercial medical marijuana businesses
may be treated as one premises. (Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
4-8-2-5: PERMIT NONTRANSFERABLE:
A permit which has been issued by the Code Enforcement Officer of the City of
Lone Grove is nontransferable. A commercial medical marijuana business permit
is not transferable or assignable, including, without limitation, not
transferable or assignable to a different premises, to a different type of
business, or to a different owner or permittee. A commercial medical marijuana
business permit is valid only for the owner named thereon, the type of business
disclosed on the application for the permit, and the location for which the
permit is issued. The permittees of a commercial medical marijuana business
permit are only those persons disclosed in the application for the permit, and
the location for which the permit is issued. The permittees of a commercial
medical marijuana business permit are only those persons disclosed in the
application or subsequently disclosed to the City in accordance with this
chapter. (Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
4-8-3: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
4-8-3-1: DEFENSE TO PROSECUTIONS:
Compliance with the requirements of this chapter shall not provide an
exception, immunity, or defense to criminal prosecution under any applicable
law, except in the Lone Grove Municipal Court, for a violation of this chapter
as specifically provided herein. (Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
4-8-3-2: AUTHORITY TO INSPECT:
Every medical marijuana dispensary, commercial grower, and processor shall
permit the local permitting authority, and any agent of the local permitting
authority, or anyone authorized, to inspect the premises of the business
pursuant to this Code, or any appropriate Federal or State Statute or
regulation. (Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
4-8-3-3: COSTS OF INSPECTIONS AND CLEAN-UP:
In the event the City incurs costs in the inspection, cleanup, surrender of
plants, or any expense related to a medical marijuana business, the business
and responsible person shall reimburse the City for all actual costs incurred
by the City. The business and responsible person shall also be responsible for
reasonable attorney fees. (Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
4-8-3-4: RESERVED:
(Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
4-8-3-5: RESERVED:
(Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
4-8-3-6: FORFEITURE OF PERMIT:
In the event that a commercial medical marijuana business does not commence
