Notes
1 1. See section
  11-1-8 of this code for fees.
10-3-1: USE OF CITY SEWER REQUIRED:
   A.   Any residential dwelling or commercial building constructed within the
corporate limits of the city, regardless of type of structure, shall be
required, without exception, to use and accept sewer services furnished by the
city, regardless of the purposes the sewer is used for, if the residential
dwelling or commercial building is located on a property and a lot line for
that property is within three hundred feet (300') of a new or existing city
sewer line of any type or nature.
   B.   All costs and expenses incident to the installation and/or connection
of a residence or building shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall
indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be
caused by the installation of or the building of a sewer. (Ord. 2008-226, 9-30-
2008, eff. 10-30-2008)
10-3-2: SEWAGE BACKFLOW:
   A.   A backflow device shall be installed on all new or replacement building
sewers that connect to a public sewer system.
   B.   The property owner shall be responsible for installation, continued
inspection, maintenance, repair and replacement of all backflow device systems.
   C.   A backflow device system shall be installed so that access is provided
to the working parts for service and repair. If installed under concrete or
asphalt paving such as sidewalks, driveways, or parking areas a backflow device
system shall be installed in a permanent box or installed under soil and ground
cover vegetation, where a backflow device system is considered to be
accessible.
   D.   All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and/or connection
of a building, business, or residence shall be borne by the owner. The owner
shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or
indirectly be caused by the installation of or the building of a backflow
device. (Ord. 2015-253, 1-20-2015, eff. 4-20-2015)
10-3-3: PROHIBITED AND RESTRICTED DISCHARGES; INDUSTRIAL WASTES:
   A.   Prohibited Discharges: No person shall discharge or cause to be
discharged the following substances if it appears likely, in the opinion of the
code enforcement officer or other designated employee that such wastes can harm
the sewers, the sewage treatment process or equipment, have an adverse effect
on the receiving stream, or can otherwise endanger life, limb, or public
property, or otherwise constitute a nuisance. The prohibited substances are:
      1.   Flammable or explosive materials;
      2.   Waters or wastes containing fats, wax, grease, or oils in excess of
Oklahoma department of environmental quality (DEQ) regulations or containing
any substance which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures higher than
thirty two degrees Fahrenheit (32°F);
      3.   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred
fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F);
      4.   Any garbage or food waste not properly shredded. The installation
and operation of any grinder or shredder equipped with a motor of three-fourths
(3/4) horsepower or greater shall be subject to review and approval by the code
enforcement officer or other designated employee;
      5.   Any waters or wastes containing any of the metals listed below or
other toxic substances in quantities determined by the code enforcement officer
or other designated employee to be harmful:
Antimony
Arsenic
Barium
Beryllium
Bismuth
Boron
Cadmium
Chromium
Cobalt
Copper
Iron
Lead
Manganese
Mercury
Molybdenum
Nickel
Rhenium
Selenium
Silver
Strontium
Tellurium
Tin
Uranium
Zinc
      6.   Any waters or wastes containing iron pickling wastes or plating
solutions;
      7.   Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste or odor
producing substances;
      8.   Any radioactive wastes of a half-life or concentration determined by
the code enforcement officer or other designated employee to be harmful;
      9.   Any waters or wastes having pH lower than 5.5, or having any
corrosive property capable of damaging installations, equipment, or personnel
of the sewage works;
      10.   Solid or viscous substances of such size or in such quantities
capable of causing obstruction of sewers or interference with operation of
sewage works, such as ashes, cinders, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags,
feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure,
hair, fleshings, entrails, and paper containers;
      11.   Wastes containing unusual concentrations of suspended solids, such
as fuller's earth, lime, or clay;
      12.   Wastes containing unusual concentrations of dissolved substances,
such as sodium chloride or sodium sulfate;
      13.   Waters or wastes containing excessive coloration, such as that
caused by dye wastes and tanning solutions;
      14.   Wastes containing unusual concentrations of organic material, such
as whey, milk, yeast, blood, or unusual biochemical oxygen demand (BOD),
chemical oxygen demand (COD), or chlorine requirement, constituting a
significant load on the sewage treatment facilities; and
      15.   Materials which cause unusual volume of flow or concentration of
wastes constituting slugs which adversely affect the sewage treatment process.
   B.   Discharged Substances; Action By City:
      1.   If any waters or wastes are discharged or proposed to be discharged
which contain the substances described in subsection A of this section, the
code enforcement officer or other designated employee may:
         a.   Prohibit their discharge;
         b.   Require the responsible party to pretreat the wastes before
discharge;
         c.   Limit the quantity, rates, and times of discharge;
         d.   Require the installation of a control manhole for observation,
sampling, and metering of the wastes; and
         e.   Assess a surcharge based on the quantity and strength of the
wastes.
      2.   If pretreatment is to be accomplished, the design, installation, and
operation of the plant and equipment shall be subject to the review and
approval of the code enforcement officer or other designated employee.
   C.   Industrial Wastes:
      1.   Application For Permit: Applications for permits for sewer
connections for industrial wastes shall show the following information:
         a.   A plat of the property showing all existing sewers and storm
drains;
         b.   Plans and specifications covering any work proposed to be done
under the permit;
         c.   A schedule of all process waters and industrial wastes produced
or to be produced, a description of the character of each waste, the daily
volumes and maximum rate of discharge, and representative analyses; and
         d.   The name of the firm or person who will perform the work covered
by the application.
      2.   Analyses: The code enforcement officer or other designated employee
shall cause samples of wastes from industrial establishments to be obtained and
tested periodically to determine the quantity and composition thereof. (1990
Code § 17-401; amd. 2006 Code; Ord. 2008-226, 9-30-2008, eff. 10-30-2008; Ord.
2015-253, 1-20-2015, eff. 4-20-2015)
      3.   Charges: Where industrial wastes having excessive concentrations of
suspended solids or biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) are permitted to be
discharged into the city sewer system, a surcharge shall be levied in addition
to the charges established under the rate schedule. The surcharge shall be for
each pound of suspended solids in excess of department of environmental quality
regulations. The specific charges shall be as set by the board of trustees of
the Lone Grove water and sewer trust authority. (1990 Code § 17-402; amd. 2006
Code; Ord. 2008-226, 9-30-2008, eff. 10-30-2008; Ord. 2015-253, 1-20-2015, eff.
4-20-2015)
   D.   Notice Of Violations; Enforcement: The code enforcement officer or
other designated employee shall cause to be served on the owner or occupant of
any establishment having sewer connections which do not conform to the
provisions hereof a notice in writing advising that requirements must be met
within thirty (30) days. If, after thirty (30) days from the date of service of
the notice, the proper measures have not been taken, enforcement action may be
initiated as set forth in section
10-3-6 of this chapter. (1990 Code § 17-401; amd. 2006 Code; Ord. 2008-226, 9-
30-2008, eff. 10-30-2008; Ord. 2015-253, 1-20-2015, eff. 4-20-2015)
10-3-4: SEPTIC TANKS:
   A.   Standards Adopted: The city council hereby adopts and incorporates by
reference herein the official state department of health bulletin number 600,
in its entirety, as to installation of septic systems in the city. (1990 Code §
5-801; amd. 2006 Code; Ord. 2008-226, 9-30-2008, eff. 10-30-2008; Ord. 2015-
253, 1-20-2015, eff. 4-20-2015)
   B.   State Approval Required: Any person, firm, partnership, corporation,
and/or contractor, prior to securing a building permit from the city, shall
complete the state department of health form 581 and secure approval from the
state department of health for all septic tank systems for any planned
residential and/or commercial construction. The appropriate city officer shall
not issue a building permit for any residential and/or commercial construction
in the corporate limits of the city unless the applicant therefor shall first
produce proof of approval of the septic tank system proposed by the state
department of health and completion of state department of health form 581.
(1990 Code §§ 5-803, 5-804; amd. Ord. 2008-226, 9-30-2008, eff. 10-30-2008;
Ord. 2015-253, 1-20-2015, eff. 4-20-2015)
10-3-5: LAGOONS:
   A.   Planning Commission Review: Any person, corporation, partnership, or
entity desiring to construct or maintain a lagoon system within the corporate
limits of the city must first cause proper plans, specifications, and/or
engineering drawings of the lagoon system to be placed on the regular agenda of
the planning commission of the city. The submission of the plans,
specifications, or drawings shall be submitted to the planning commission prior
to the construction of any work on the lagoon system. (1990 Code § 5-812; amd.
Ord. 2008-226, 9-30-2008, eff. 10-30-2008; Ord. 2015-253, 1-20-2015, eff. 4-20-
2015)
   B.   Standards For Planning Commission Review: The planning commission is
authorized and directed to review all lagoon applications, and to make
recommendations to the city council for approval or rejection of the proposed
lagoon system, and reasons therefor, according to the following standards:
      1.   The proposed site is not potentially injurious to the health, safety
or welfare of the public;
      2.   The proposed site is not located in or adjacent to a residential
area, school site, or flood hazard area, where a probability of contamination
exists;
      3.   The proposed site must utilize no less than three (3) cells, one
retention cell and two (2) overflow cells, and be constructed in accordance
with state health department standards;
      4.   No other sewage disposal system is possible for the proposed
construction regardless of designated lot sizes;
      5.   The city reserves the right to refuse dedication into the city sewer
system; and
      6.   The constructor of the lagoon shall remain responsible for
maintenance according to state health department and city standards. (1990 Code
§ 5-813; amd. Ord. 2008-226, 9-30-2008, eff. 10-30-2008; Ord. 2015-253, 1-20-
2015, eff. 4-20-2015)
   C.   Council Approval: All lagoon systems constructed within the corporate
limits of the city shall be approved by the city council prior to actual
construction of the lagoon system. (1990 Code § 5-811; amd. Ord. 2008-226, 9-
30-2008, eff. 10-30-2008; Ord. 2015-253, 1-20-2015, eff. 4-20-2015)
   D.   Fence Requirements:
      1.   Fence Required: No lagoon shall be constructed within the corporate
limits of the city unless same shall be completely enclosed with a well
constructed fence, no less than five feet (5') in height, same to be of durable
materials to prevent entry by persons of tender age and animals of any type or
description.
      2.   Construction Materials: All fences surrounding lagoon systems shall
be durable chainlink or stockade wood materials, and shall include materials
constructed at the top portion thereof designed to prevent unauthorized
entrance.
      3.   Gate: All lagoon systems enclosed by fences shall include a durable,
well constructed gate, which shall be securely locked by the owner or operators
thereof at all times to prevent unauthorized entrance as provided herein. (1990
Code § 5-810; amd. Ord. 2008-226, 9-30-2008, eff. 10-30-2008; Ord. 2015-253, 1-
20-2015, eff. 4-20-2015)
10-3-6: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, corporation, partnership, or entity who violates any of the
provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon
conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1990 Code § 5-814; amd. Ord. 2008-226, 9-30-2008, eff. 10-
30-2008; Ord. 2015-253, 1-20-2015, eff. 4-20-2015)
10-3-7: WASTEWATER TREATMENT SYSTEM (WTS) AND FACILITY (WWTF):
   A.   Purpose And Policy; Compliance With State And Federal Laws, Rules, And
Regulations: This section sets forth uniform requirements for direct and
indirect contributors into the wastewater collection and treatment system of
the city and enables the city to comply with applicable state and federal laws
required by the federal clean water act of 1977, and the federal general
pretreatment regulations (40 CFR, part 403, as amended). This includes
compliance with all state and federal rules and regulations for wastewater and
wastewater treatment facilities administered by the state's department of
environmental quality (DEQ).
   B.   Objectives:
      1.   The objectives of this section are:
         a.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the municipal
wastewater system which will interfere with the operation of the system or
contaminate the resulting sludge;
         b.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the municipal
wastewater system which will pass through the system, inadequately treated,
into receiving waters or the atmosphere; or otherwise be incompatible with the
system;
         c.   To improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewaters and
sludges from the system;
         d.   To provide for the equitable distribution of the cost of the
municipal wastewater system;
         e.   To protect both publicly owned treatment works (POTW) personnel
who may be affected by wastewater and sludge in the course of their employment
and the general public; and
         f.   To enable the city to comply with its national pollutant
discharge elimination system (NPDES) permit conditions, sludge use and disposal
requirements, and any other federal or state laws to which the publicly owned
treatment works is subject.
      2.   This section provides for the regulation of direct and indirect
contributors to the municipal wastewater system through the issuance of
permits/taps to certain nondomestic users and through the enforcement of
general requirements for the other users, authorizes monitoring and enforcement
activities, requires user reporting, assumes that the existing customer's
capacity will not be preempted and provides for the setting of fees for the
equitable distribution of the costs resulting from the program established in
this section.
      3.   This section shall apply to the city and to persons outside the city
who are, by contract or agreement with the city, users of the city publicly
owned treatment works.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, the control authority designated
by the city shall administer, implement and enforce the provisions of this
section.
   C.   Definitions: Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the
following terms and phrases as used in this section shall have the meanings
designated in this subsection:
    ACT AND THE ACT: The federal water pollution control act, also known as the
clean water act, as amended, 33 USC 1251 et seq.
   ADMINISTRATOR: The administrator of the U.S. environmental protection agency
(EPA).
   APPROVAL AUTHORITY: The director in an NPDES state with an approved state
pretreatment program and the administrator of the environmental protection
agency in a non-NPDES state or NPDES state without an approved state
pretreatment program.
   AUTHORIZED REPRESENTATIVE: The authorized representative of a municipality
who may be:
      1.   If the user is a federal, state or local governmental facility; a
director or highest official appointed or designated to oversee the operation
and performance of the activities of the government facility or their designee.
   BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (BOD): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the
biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure,
five (5) days at twenty degrees Celsius (20°C) expressed in terms of weight and
concentration (milligrams per liter (mg/l)).
   BUILDING SEWER: A sewer conveying wastewater from the premises of a user to
the publicly owned treatment works.
   CATEGORICAL STANDARDS: National categorical pretreatment standards or
pretreatment standard.
   CITY: The city or the city council of the city.
   COMPOSITE SAMPLE: A sample that is collected over time, formed either by
continuous sampling or by mixing discrete samples. The sample may be composited
either as a time composite sample or as a flow proportional composite sample.
   CONTROL AUTHORITY: The "approval authority", defined in this subsection, or
the office of the city manager or designee.
   COOLING WATER: The water discharged from any use, such as air conditioning,
cooling, refrigeration or to which the only pollutant added is heat.
   DIRECT DISCHARGE: The discharge of treated or untreated wastewater directly
to the waters of the state.
   ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY AND EPA: The U.S. environmental protection
agency; or, where appropriate, the term may also be used as a designation for
the administrator or other duly authorized official of such agency.
   EXTRA STRENGTH WASTEWATER: Wastewater having a biochemical oxygen demand
greater than two hundred milligrams per liter (200 mg/l), and/or a total
suspended solids content greater than one hundred fifty milligrams per liter
(150 mg/l) and/or a total kjeldahl nitrogen content greater than thirty
milligrams per liter (30 mg/l).
   GRAB SAMPLE: A sample which is taken from a waste stream on a onetime basis
with no regard to the flow in the waste stream and not exceeding fifteen (15)
minutes.
   HOLDING TANK WASTE: Any waste from holding tanks, such as vessels, chemical
toilets, campers, trailers, septic tanks and vacuum pump tank trucks.
   INDIRECT DISCHARGE: The discharge or the introduction of nondomestic
pollutants from any source, regulated under section 307(b), (c) or (d) of the
act (33 USC 1317), into the publicly owned treatment works, including holding
tank waste discharged into the system.
   INDUSTRIAL USER: A source of indirect discharge which does not constitute a
discharge of pollutants under regulations issued pursuant to section 402 of the
act (33 USC 1342).
   INTERFERENCE: The inhibition or disruption of the publicly owned treatment
works treatment processes or operations or its sludge processes, use or
disposal which contributes to a violation of any requirement of the city's
NPDES permit.
   MAXIMUM ALLOWABLE DISCHARGE LIMIT: The maximum allowable concentration of a
pollutant determined from the analysis of any discrete or composited sample
collected, independent of the industrial flow rate and the duration of the
sampling event.
   NPDES PERMIT: The prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal by the
publicly owned treatment works in accordance with section 405 of the act (33
USC 1345) or any criteria, guidelines or regulations developed pursuant to the
solid waste disposal act (SWDA), the clean air act, the toxic substances
control act or more stringent state criteria (including those contained in any
state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to title IV of the SWDA)
applicable to the method of disposal or use employed by the publicly owned
treatment works.
   NATIONAL CATEGORICAL PRETREATMENT STANDARD AND PRETREATMENT STANDARD: Any
regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA in
accordance with section 307(b) and (c) of the act (33 USC 1317), which applies
to a specific category of users and which appears in 40 CFR chapter 1,
subchapter N, parts 405-471.
   NATIONAL POLLUTION DISCHARGE ELIMINATION SYSTEM AND NPDES PERMIT: A permit
issued pursuant to section 402 of the act (33 USC 1342).
   NATIONAL PROHIBITIVE DISCHARGE STANDARD AND PROHIBITIVE DISCHARGE STANDARD:
Any regulation developed under the act authority of section 307(b) of the act
and 40 CFR 403.5.
   NEW SOURCE: Any building, structure, facility or installation from which
there is or may be a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which
commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under
section 307(c) of the act which will be applicable to such source if such
standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section; provided
that:
      1.   The building, structure, facility or installation is constructed at
a site at which no other source is located;
      2.   The building, structure, facility or installation totally replaces
the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at
an existing source; or
      3.   The production or wastewater generating processes of the building,
structure, facility or installation are substantially independent of an
existing source at the same site. In determining whether substantially
independent factors exist (such as the extent to which the new facility is
integrated with the existing plant and the extent to which the new facility is
engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source) the
following should be considered:
         a. Construction on a site at which an existing source is located
results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not
create a new building, structure, facility or installation meeting the criteria
of this section but otherwise alters, replaces or adds to existing process or
production equipment.
         b. Construction of a "new source", as defined under this subsection C,
has commenced if the owner or operator has:
            (1) Begun or caused to begin as part of a continuous on site
construction program:
               (A) Any placement, assembly or installation of facilities or
equipment;
               (B) Significant site preparation work, including clearing,
excavating or removal of existing buildings, structures or facilities, which is
necessary for the placement, assembly or installation of new source facilities
or equipment; or
            (2) Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase
of facilities or equipment which is intended to be used in its operation within
a reasonable time. Options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or
modified without substantial loss and contracts for feasibility, engineering
and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this
subsection.
   NONCONTACT COOLING WATER: Water used for cooling which does not come into
direct contact with any raw material, intermediate product, waste product or
finished product.
   PASS-THROUGH: A discharge which exits the publicly owned treatment works
into waters in quantities or concentrations which, alone or in conjunction with
a discharge or discharges from other sources, is a cause of a violation of any
requirements of the city's NPDES permit, including an increase in the magnitude
or duration of a violation.
   PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company,
corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental
entity or any other legal entity or their legal representatives, agents or
assigns. The masculine gender shall include the feminine; the singular shall
include the plural where indicated by the context.
   pH: The logarithm (base-10) of the reciprocal of the concentration of
hydrogen ions, expressed in grams per liter (g/l) of solution.
   POLLUTANT: Any dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage,
garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials,
radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discharged equipment, rock, sand,
cellar dirt and industrial, municipal and agricultural waste discharged into
water.
   POLLUTION: The manmade or man induced alteration of the chemical, physical,
biological and radiological integrity of water.
   PRETREATMENT AND TREATMENT: The reduction of the amount of pollutants, the
elimination of pollutants or the alteration of the nature of pollutant
properties in wastewater to a less harmful state prior to, or in lieu of,
discharging or otherwise introducing such pollutants into a publicly owned
treatment works. The reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical,
chemical or biological processes or process changes by other means except as
prohibited by 40 CFR 403.6(d).
   PRETREATMENT REQUIREMENTS: Any substantive or procedural requirement related
to pretreatment other than a national pretreatment standard imposed on an
industrial user.
   PUBLICLY OWNED TREATMENT WORKS (POTW): A treatment work, as defined by
section 212 of the act (33 USC 1292), which is owned in this instance by the
city. This definition includes any sewers that convey wastewater to the
publicly owned treatment works treatment plant, but does not include pipes,
sewers or other conveyances not connected to a facility providing treatment.
For the purposes of this section, the term "publicly owned treatment works"
shall also include any sewers that convey wastewaters to the publicly owned
treatment works from persons outside the city who are, by contract or agreement
with the city, users of the city's publicly owned treatment works.
   PUBLICLY OWNED TREATMENT WORKS TREATMENT PLANT: That portion of the publicly
owned treatment works designed to provide treatment (including recycling and
reclamation) of municipal sewage and industrial waste.
   SIGNIFICANT INDUSTRIAL USER: Any industrial user of the city's wastewater
disposal system who:
      1.   Is subject to federal categorical pretreatment standards under 40
CFR 403.6, and/or 40 CFR chapter I, subchapter N;
      2.   Has a discharge flow of twenty five thousand (25,000) gallons or
more per average workday of process wastewater;
      3.   Has a process waste stream which makes up five percent (5%) or more
of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the city's
wastewater treatment system; or
      4.   Is found by the city, state control agency or the EPA to have a
reasonable potential for adversely affecting, either singly or in combination
with other contributing industries, the publicly owned treatment works'
operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement, in
accordance with 40 CFR 403.8(f)(6). Upon a finding that an industrial user
meeting the criteria for significant industrial user has no reasonable
potential for adversely affecting the publicly owned treatment works' operation
or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement, the control
authority, as defined in 40 CFR 403.12(a) of the act, may at any time, on its
own initiative or in response to a petition received from an industrial user of
the publicly owned treatment works, and in accordance with 40 CFR 403.8(f)(6)
of the act, determine that such industrial user is not a significant industrial
user.
   SLUG LOAD: Any discharge of a nonroutine, episodic nature, including, but
not limited to, an accidental spill or noncustomary batch discharge.
   SMALL VOLUME/QUANTITY DISCHARGER OF SILVER: Discharger of less than twenty
five (25) gpd of silver rich solutions.
   STANDARD INDUSTRIAL CLASSIFICATION (SIC): A classification pursuant to the
"Standard Industrial Classification Manual", issued by the executive office of
the president, office of management and budget, 1972.
   STORMWATER: Any flow occurring during or following any form of natural
precipitation and resulting therefrom.
   SUSPENDED SOLIDS: The total suspended matter that floats on the surface of,
or is suspended in water, wastewater or other liquids, and which is removable
by laboratory filtering.
   TOTAL KJELDAHL NITROGEN: The nitrogen content, including both ammonia
nitrogen and organic nitrogen, found using the kjeldahl method of analysis.
   TOTAL TOXIC ORGANICS: The total of any organic chemicals listed in 40 CFR
122, appendix D, table II.
   TOXIC POLLUTANT: Any pollutant or combination of pollutants listed as toxic
in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the environmental protection
agency under the provision of CWA 307(a) or other acts.
   USER: Any person who contributes, causes or permits the contribution of
wastewater into the city's publicly owned treatment works.
   WASTEWATER: The liquid and water carried industrial or domestic wastes from
dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial facilities and institutions,
together with any groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be
present, whether treated or untreated, which is contributed into or permitted
to enter the publicly owned treatment works.
   WATERS OF THE STATE: All streams, lakes, ponds, marshes, watercourses,
waterways, wells, springs, reservoirs, aquifers, irrigation systems, drainage
systems and all other bodies or accumulations of water, surface or underground,
natural or artificial, public or private, which are contained within, flow
through or border upon the state or any portion thereof.
   D.   Abbreviations: The following abbreviations shall have the designated
meanings:
 
BOD   Biochemical oxygen demand
CFR   Code of federal regulations
COD   Chemical oxygen demand
DEQ   Department of environmental quality
EPA   Environmental protection agency
l     Liter
mg    Milligrams
mg/l  Milligrams per liter
NPDES National pollutant discharge elimination system
O&M   Operation and maintenance
POTW  Publicly owned treatment works
RCRA  Resource conservation and recovery act
SIC   Standard industrial classification
SWDA  Solid waste disposal act, 42 USC 6901 et seq.
TKN   Total kjeldahl nitrogen
TSS   Total suspended solids
TTO   Total toxic organics
USC   United States Code
 
(Ord. 2009-227, 1-20-2009; amd. Ord. 2015-253, 1-20-2015, eff. 4-20-2015)
CHAPTER 4
SOLID WASTE SYSTEM
SECTION:
10-4-1: Definitions
10-4-2: Duty To Request Garbage Service
10-4-3: Water Customers Deemed Sanitation Department Customers
10-4-4: Containers
10-4-5: Preparation Of Rubbish For Collection
10-4-6: Collection And Disposal Of Solid Waste
10-4-7: Burning Solid Waste
10-4-8: Scavenging Prohibited
10-4-9: Charges For Service
10-4-10: Inspections
10-4-11: Penalty
10-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section:
GARBAGE: All putrescible wastes, except sewage and bodily wastes, including all
meats, vegetable and fruit refuse, and carcasses of small animals and fowl from
any premises within the corporate limits.
PERSON: Any institution, public or private corporation, individual,
partnership, or other entity.
PREMISES: Land, buildings or other structure, vehicles, watercraft, or parts
thereof, upon or in which refuse is stored.
REFUSE: All solid wastes, including garbage and rubbish.
RUBBISH: Tin cans, bottles, papers, tree limbs from any premises within the
corporate limits.
RUBBLE: Brushwood, card board boxes and other bulky earthen, wooden, or metal
refuselike materials, longer, larger and/or heavier than refuse.
STATE OR COUNTY HEALTH OFFICER: The state or county health officer of the
county or the state or his authorized agent. (1990 Code § 17-301; amd. 2006
Code)
10-4-2: DUTY TO REQUEST GARBAGE SERVICE:
To assist in maintaining the general sanitation of the city, it is the duty of
every person occupying or having control of the occupancy of any premises
located on a regularly established garbage route to notify the city water
department at the beginning of such occupancy and request, accept and use the
garbage pick up and collection service (Southern Oklahoma rural disposal
service [SDRD]). The failure of any owner, rental agent or occupant of such
premises to make such request, however, shall not prevent nor in any way impair
or impede the city from adding that person's name to the garbage collection
records and providing such service and otherwise enforcing, by appropriate
action, the regulatory measures herein prescribed and causing the fees or
charges therefor to be paid. (1990 Code § 17-307; amd. 2006 Code)
10-4-3: WATER CUSTOMERS DEEMED SANITATION DEPARTMENT CUSTOMERS:
Any person or entity making application for water service with the Lone Grove
water and sewerage authority or posting a deposit with the city water
department shall be deemed to have applied also for garbage services and shall
be considered a customer of the sanitation department of the city until such
time as water service to such customer has been discontinued. (1990 Code § 17-
312)
10-4-4: CONTAINERS:
   A.   General Requirements: It is the duty of every person, firm or
corporation owning, managing, operating, leasing or renting any premises or any
place where refuse accumulates, to provide, and at all times maintain in good
order and repair, on any of the premises, a portable container or containers
for refuse, which container is rodentproof and flyproof, and of sufficient
capacity and in sufficient numbers to accommodate and securely keep all of the
refuse that may accumulate between collections, except where approved type bulk
containers are in use. All containers shall be kept clean and free from the
accumulation of any substance remaining attached to the inside of the container
which would attract flies, mosquitoes or any other insects.
   B.   Specifications: Each container shall have a capacity of not less than
twenty (20) gallons nor more than thirty two (32) gallons, except where
approved type bulk containers are in use.
   C.   Placement For Pick Up: All residents of the city who utilize garbage
and solid waste pick up service by employees or agents of the city shall be
required to place garbage cans or trash containers near the curb site of
designated routes for pick up service. All customers of the city shall be
required to place the garbage cans at the curb site abutting their properties
for convenient pick up by sanitation employees.
   D.   Maintenance Of Area Around Containers: All containers and grounds
immediately around the same shall be kept in a safe and sanitary condition at
all times. (1990 Code § 17-302)
10-4-5: PREPARATION OF RUBBISH FOR COLLECTION:
All ordinary accumulations of rubbish such as tree limbs, paper boxes, and
scrap lumber which cannot be conveniently placed in the containers required
under this chapter shall be gathered together and baled, tied or sacked in
compact bundles, of lengths not exceeding three and one-half feet (31/2'),
including leaves and branches, weighing no more than fifty (50) pounds, and
placed in a location easily accessible to the collector. (1990 Code § 17-302;
amd. 2006 Code)
10-4-6: COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE:
   A.   Schedule Of Collection; Placement Of Containers: The city or its
authorized representative shall collect garbage according to the schedule set
by the city council. It is the duty of any person in possession or control of
any premises to place all refuse, garbage or rubbish in the appropriate
containers.
   B.   Animal Carcasses: Carcasses of animals, such as cows, horses and mules,
shall be removed and disposed of at the expense of the owner or person having
same in charge and by the method directed by the state health officer.
   C.   Heavy, Bulky Items: Heavy accumulations such as brush, broken concrete,
ashes, sand or gravel, automobile frames, dead trees, and other bulky, heavy
materials shall be disposed of at the expense of the owner or person
controlling same under the direction of the county health officer. (1990 Code §
17-304)
   D.   Oils And Hazardous Materials: Waste oils from garages or filling
stations or materials considered hazardous or dangerous, shall be removed and
disposed of at the expense of the person controlling same in the manner and by
the method directed by the county health officer. (1990 Code § 17-304; amd.
2006 Code)
   E.   Methods Of Disposal:
      1.   The placing of garbage or rubbish or any refuse material in any
street or alley within the city limits or the disposal of such refuse at any
place within the city limits, except at the city disposal ground, or at such
other place as may be directed by the county health officer, is prohibited.
(1990 Code § 17-303)
      2.   The disposal of garbage and rubbish shall be by an approved method
of incineration (not open burning) or by landfill and daily covering pursuant
to regulations of the state department of health. (1990 Code § 17-304)
10-4-7: BURNING SOLID WASTE:
There shall be no open burning on premises, unless the operations are carried
out in an approved type incinerator, or approval is obtained from the county
health officer or the fire chief. (1990 Code § 17-302; amd. 2006 Code)
10-4-8: SCAVENGING PROHIBITED:
The meddling with refuse containers or in any way pilfering, scattering
contents, or junking in any alley or street within the city limits is
prohibited. (1990 Code § 17-303)
10-4-9: CHARGES FOR SERVICE:
   A.   Charges Established And On File: There shall be charged, assessed and
collected from each residential unit and each commercial establishment within
the city limits a monthly amount as set by the city council by resolution or
motion, or by agreement with its authorized representative. A copy of the
current fees in effect shall be kept in the city clerk's office. (1990 Code §
17-306)
   B.   Bills For Service:
      1.   Charges On Water Bill; Payment In Full Required:
         a.   All bills for garbage or sanitation service charges shall be
included on water bills, and no payment shall be accepted by the city or the
Lone Grove water and sewer trust authority except for the full amount billed
for all services, and delinquent refuse bills shall carry the due dates, grace
periods and penalties as do water bills. (1990 Code § 17-308)
         b.   The charges billed shall constitute a total utility charge for
the month in question, and partial payments for the services are prohibited. In
the event an amount is paid less than the amount billed, the bill shall be
considered delinquent as to the amount unpaid, and subsection C of this section
shall be applicable. (1990 Code § 17-311)
      2.   Payment Of Bills:
         a.   The refuse charges shall be payable monthly as and in accordance
with the city's billing schedule. (1990 Code § 17-308; amd. 2006 Code)
         b.   All bills for garbage or sanitation service shall be paid to the
city when due. Penalties shall be assessed to the billing in the event of
delinquency. (1990 Code § 17-309)
   C.   Delinquent Payments: All charges assessed under this chapter shall be
due and payable by the tenth of each month. Failure to pay any charge assessed
under this chapter within thirty (30) days from the tenth of the month the
charges are billed shall be considered notice by the customer to discontinue
water service and garbage service and shall be deemed notice to apply so much
of the customer's water deposit as is necessary to the satisfaction of the past
due bill. In such case, no water, sewerage or garbage service may be
recommenced to the customer of the original deposit until the charge for
turning on the customer's water shall has been paid. A penalty of ten percent
(10%) of the charges billed shall be assessed after the fifteenth of the month
the charges are mailed to the customer, in the event the bill is delinquent.
(1990 Code § 17-310)
10-4-10: INSPECTIONS:
It is the duty of the city police chief or his authorized agent, or the city
health officer, to make all necessary inspections and investigations of any and
all premises to see that the terms of this chapter are complied with. (1990
Code § 17-305)
10-4-11: PENALTY:
Any person found violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1990 Code § 17-313)
TITLE 11
BUILDING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL BUILDING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
11-1-1: Enforcement Officer
11-1-2: Scope Of Regulations
11-1-3: Fire Limits
11-1-4: Permit Requirements
11-1-5: Construction Requirements
11-1-5-1: Roofing Contractors
11-1-6: Certificate Of Approval
11-1-7: Moving Buildings
11-1-8: Fee Schedule
11-1-9: Variances
11-1-10: Appeals
11-1-11: Penalty
11-1-1: ENFORCEMENT OFFICER:
The code enforcement officer of the city shall be the enforcement official for
the city building regulations and shall have the powers and duties prescribed
for the building official by the building code. (2006 Code)
11-1-2: SCOPE OF REGULATIONS:
It is hereby declared to be the intent of the city council that all housing for
human habitation and commercial structures shall conform to certain minimum
requirements for the health and safety of the citizens of the city. (1990 Code
§ 5-102)
11-1-3: FIRE LIMITS:
The fire limits are that part of the city bounded as determined by the city
council. (1990 Code § 5-205)
11-1-4: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS 1 :
   A.   Permit And Statement Required: No wall, structure, building, sign or
part thereof shall hereafter be built, enlarged, altered or remodeled within
the corporate limits of the city until a plan of the proposed work, together
with a statement of the building owner or contractor, shall have been submitted
to the city's code enforcement officer who shall issue a permit for the
proposed construction or remodeling after review and approval of the submitted
documents. The required statement of the building owner or contractor shall
consist of the proposed cost of the building or remodeling, the type of
structure, and the precise area where the building is to be located, and the
precise layout, including dimensions. The statement submitted to the city clerk
of Lone Grove shall reflect the total monetary value of the proposed structure
and/or remodeling expense for which the city permit shall be issued. The total
value of the proposed structure for which the permit is to be issued shall
include all labor, material, equipment, overhead and contractor's profit,
together with the cost of plumbing, heating, wiring and painting included in
such structure. (Ord. 2006-218, 10-16-2006, eff. 11-16-2006)
   B.   Fees: The code enforcement officer shall collect the sums established
in section
11-1-8 of this chapter prior to issuance of a permit to an applicant for same.
(1990 Code § 5-114; amd. Ord. 210, 10-20-2003, eff. 11-21-2003; 2006 Code)
   C.   Compliance With Zoning Regulations: The code enforcement officer shall
not grant and issue a building permit unless the proposed building or
alteration is in harmony with the zoning ordinance of the city. (1990 Code § 5-
105)
   D.   Display Of Permit: The person and/or entity securing a permit from the
code enforcement officer shall post same conspicuously on the building where
the construction and/or remodeling is to be done.
   E.   Penalty: Should any person actually begin construction, alteration,
repair, removal and/or remodeling of any building without first taking out a
permit therefor, such person and/or entity shall be guilty of an offense and,
upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section
11-1-11 of this chapter. (1990 Code § 5-105; amd. 2006 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  12-2-2 of this code.
11-1-5: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Plans And Specifications: Plans and specifications of proposed
dwellings, homes, buildings, etc., shall be submitted to the code enforcement
officer and to the chairman of the planning commission. (1990 Code § 5-114;
amd. 2006 Code)
   B.   Compliance With Zoning Regulations: All construction in the city shall
meet or exceed all requirements of the zoning ordinances of the city. (1990
Code § 5-114)
11-1-5-1: ROOFING CONTRACTORS:
   A.   The roofing contractor registration act is attached as an addendum to
the ordinance codified herein as a reference and is made a part of this section
by reference.
   B.   A roofing contractor operating within the city limits of Lone Grove
shall be properly registered with the state as provided for in the act.
   C.   A roofing contractor shall comply with state laws and local ordinances
relating to standards and permits and operation with the city limits of Lone
Grove as provided for in the act.
   D.   A roofing contractor shall present to the city a certificate of
registration.
   E.   A roofing contractor shall present to the city a certificate of
liability in an amount of not less than five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00).
   F.   A roofing contractor shall present to the city proof of satisfactory
coverage of workers' compensation liability or an affidavit of exemption.
   G.   A roofing contractor shall pay an initial registration fee as specified
in section
11-1-8 of this chapter to the city of Lone Grove for a license to operate
within the city limits.
   H.   A roofing contractor shall pay a renewal fee as specified in section
11-1-8 of this chapter.
   I.   A roofing contractor's license renewal with the city shall coincide
with contractor's date of birth.
   J.   A building permit fee as specified in section
11-1-8 of this chapter shall be assessed for roofing inspection, single
application.
   K.   Exemptions to registration within the city limits of Lone Grove shall
be the same as exemptions listed by the state.
   L.   A person who violates any provision of the act or this section within
the city limits of Lone Grove shall be guilty of a misdemeanor which shall be
punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 2012-
246, 10-22-2012, eff. 11-22-2012)
11-1-6: CERTIFICATE OF APPROVAL:
Upon approval of a building or dwelling by the code enforcement officer, said
officer shall certify, in writing, on forms to be provided, that the dwelling
and/or building has been approved as to certain phases, or final approval.
(1990 Code § 5-111; amd. 2006 Code)
11-1-7: MOVING BUILDINGS:
   A.   Permit Required: No building of any class shall be moved from one lot
to another lot or tract of land to another location, nor from one lot or tract
of land to another lot or tract, unless a written permit therefor has been
previously secured from the code enforcement officer. (1990 Code § 5-106; amd.
2006 Code)
   B.   Permit Fee: The permit fee for moving a building of any class shall be
the sum of twenty nine dollars fifty cents ($29.50), and upon payment thereof,
the code enforcement officer shall issue the moving permit. (Ord. 2011-238, 10-
17-2011, eff. 10-17-2011)
   C.   Penalty: It is an offense and unlawful for any person in the city to
move any building or structure along or across any thoroughfare of the city
without having a permit therefor and, upon conviction thereof, the person shall
be punished as provided in section
11-1-11 of this chapter. (1990 Code § 5-106; amd. 2006 Code)

11-1-9: VARIANCES:
The code enforcement officer shall have the right to issue variance orders, in
his discretion, as to specific locations of proposed constructions, if, in the
opinion of the code enforcement officer, the variance would best serve the
general construction area, and the particular mode of the structure or dwelling
proposed to be built. The code enforcement officer shall not have the right to
require higher standards for construction of dwellings or commercial buildings
than set out in this chapter. (1990 Code § 5-109; amd. 2006 Code)
11-1-10: APPEALS:
   A.   Right Of Appeal: Any person, firm, entity, partnership, association or
corporation who is refused approval of a building or dwelling by the code
enforcement officer shall have the right of appeal to the planning commission
of the city.
   B.   Appeals To Planning Commission: The procedure for appeal shall be the
applicant's notification to the city clerk of the appeal request, and the clerk
shall log the appeal on the agenda of the next regular or special meeting of
the planning commission of the city. At the meeting, the applicant shall have
the right to be present, in person and by counsel, and shall have the right of
cross examination. After hearing evidence or statements, the planning
commission shall make its decision, by majority vote, whether to uphold,
modify, or reverse the ruling of the code enforcement officer.
   C.   Appeals To City Council:
      1.   If the applicant is aggrieved by the decision of the planning
commission, he or she may appeal to the city council, whose decision shall be
final and nonappealable.
      2.   To appeal to the city council, the applicant, within ten (10) days
from the date of the planning commission decision, shall notify the city clerk,
in writing, of his intention to appeal to the city council. Upon receipt of the
notice, the clerk shall place the item on the agenda of the next regular or
special meeting of the city council.
      3.   At the meeting, the applicant shall have the right to appear, in
person and by counsel, and shall have the right to cross examine witnesses.
      4.   After hearing evidence or statements, the city council shall vote,
by majority, whether to uphold, modify or reverse the decision of the planning
commission. The city council's decision shall be final.
   D.   Construction Ceases During Appeal Process: During the appeal process,
no construction on the proposed dwelling or building shall be allowed. (1990
Code § 5-110)
11-1-11: PENALTY:
   A.   Penalty Generally: Any person, firm or corporation who shall engage in
any business, trade or vocation for which a license, permit, certificate or
certificate of registration is required by this title, without having a valid
license, permit, certificate, or certificate of registration as required, or
who shall fail to do anything required by this title or by any code adopted by
this title, or who shall otherwise violate any provision of this title or of
any code adopted by this title, or who shall violate any lawful regulation or
order made by any of the officers provided for in this title, shall be guilty
of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code. (1990 Code § 5-1101; amd. 2006 Code)
   B.   Relief In Courts: No penalty imposed by and pursuant to this title
shall interfere with the right of the city also to apply to the proper courts
of the state for a mandamus, an injunction or other appropriate action against
such person, firm or corporation. (1990 Code § 5-1102)
CHAPTER 2
BUILDING CODES
SECTION:

11-2-2: Amendments To Code (Rep. by Ord. 2012-245, 10-22-2012, eff. 11-1-2012)

11-2-1: CODES ADOPTED:
The State of Oklahoma through the Oklahoma Uniform Building Code Commission
utilizing the Secretary of State's Office of Administrative Rules process, has
formally adopted the 2014 International Residential Code for one- and two-
family dwellings and townhouses, as amended and modified in Oklahoma
Administrative Code (OAC) 748: 20-5-1 to 20-5-23, effective November 1, 2015,
and the commercial building codes, including the 2014 International Building
Code, 2014 International Existing Building Code, 2014 International Fire Code,
2014 International Fuel Gas Code, 2014 International Mechanical Code, 2014
International Plumbing Code and the 2014 National Electrical Code, as amended
and modified in the Oklahoma Administrative Code (OAC) 748: 20-1-1 to 748: 10-
15-16, effective November 1, 2015, to be the minimum standards for residential
and commercial building codes throughout the State of Oklahoma including the
rural areas of the State, 59 Oklahoma Statutes sections 1000.20 through
1000.29.
The City of Lone Grove adopts these current amended and/or modified editions,
as well as any future editions or revisions, and amended and/or modified
versions of these codes, to be the minimum standards for residential and
commercial construction with the exception of National Electrical Code;
Concrete-Encased Electrode, article 250, section III, 250.52 item (3); in
addition it shall be required that all new construction shall use a ground rod
(s) electrode. (Ord. 2017-265, 4-17-2017, eff. 5-1-2017)
11-2-2: AMENDMENTS TO CODE:
(Rep. by Ord. 2012-245, 10-22-2012, eff. 11-1-2012)
11-2-3: PENALTY:
A person who violates a provision of this Code or fails to comply therewith or
with any of the requirements thereof, or who erects, constructs, alters,
repairs or removes, or has erected, constructed, altered, repaired, or removed
a building or structure in violation of a detailed statement or plan submitted
and approved thereunder or of a permit or certificate issued thereunder, shall
be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined any sum as
provided in section
11-1-11 of this title, including costs. Each day upon which a violation
continues shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 2017-265, 4-17-2017, eff.
5-1-2017)

11-3-1: PLUMBING CODE:
   A.   Code Adopted: The plumbing code is adopted in section
11-2-1 of this title. (Ord. 2012-245, 10-22-2012, eff. 11-1-2012)
11-3-2: PERMIT REQUIRED; FEES:
No plumbing work shall be undertaken within the city without a permit therefor
from the code enforcement officer. The fees to be paid for a plumbing permit
shall be as provided by the city council by ordinance or resolution 1 . (1990
Code § 5-304; amd. 2006 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  11-1-8 of this title.
11-3-3: PLUMBING CONTRACTORS:
   A.   Definitions: The phrases and words "journeyman plumber", "plumber's
apprentice", "plumbing contractor", and "plumbing", when used in this chapter,
shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by 59 Oklahoma Statutes
section 1001 et seq., the state plumbing license law, unless the context
clearly indicates a different meaning.
   B.   Registration Required: It is unlawful for any person to engage in the
business, trade, or occupation of a plumbing contractor (otherwise known as a
master plumber), or of a journeyman plumber, or of a plumber's apprentice in
the city unless he is registered with the city and has a current and valid
certificate of registration issued by the city. (1990 Code § 5-308)
   C.   Qualifications Of Registrants:
      1.   Only persons who have current and valid licenses as plumbing
contractors or as journeyman plumbers issued by the construction industries
board as provided by the state plumbing license law may register as such with
the city.
      2.   Only persons who have current and valid certificates of registration
as plumber's apprentices issued by the construction industries board as
provided by the law, may register as such with the city.
   D.   Certificate Of Registration; Term And Expiration Of Registration: Upon
application to the city, the city shall register such applicants and issue to
them certificates of registration. Such city certificates shall not be valid
after the termination or expiration of the state licenses or certificates.
Registration certificates of plumbing contractors and journeyman plumbers
issued as provided herein shall expire on June 30 each year. The city
certificates of plumber's apprentices shall expire when their state
certificates expire. (1990 Code § 5-308; amd. 2006 Code)
   E.   Registered Contractor: An applicant for a plumbing contractor's
certificate of registration, after complying with the laws of the state and
with this code, and after payment of the fee hereinafter specified, and showing
proof of bonds, shall be registered by the city.
   F.   Renewal Of Registration: Plumbing contractors desiring to renew their
registration shall furnish the same evidence of compliance with state licensing
laws, and the bond is required as set forth by this chapter. All plumbing
contractor registrations not renewed within ninety (90) days after the date of
expiration thereof shall be canceled, and a new application for registration
must be made and the fee for a new registration paid.
   G.   Fees: The fee for registration and renewal shall be as set by the city
council by motion or resolution 1 .
   H.   Revocation Of Registration: The city council, upon at least ten (10)
days' notice and adequate opportunity for a public hearing, may revoke the city
registration of any plumbing contractor or journeyman plumber for violating any
provisions of the ordinances or regulations of the city relating to the
installation of plumbing or for any other cause specified in the state plumbing
license law. (1990 Code § 5-308)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  11-1-8 of this title.
11-3-4: PROHIBITED SEWAGE DEPOSITS; TRAPS REQUIRED:
   A.   Certain Deposits Prohibited: The depositing of waste oil or grease in
the sanitary sewer system of the city or permitting same to be done is hereby
specifically prohibited. (1990 Code § 5-306)
   B.   Traps: Every garage, automobile service station, repair shop and car
washing rack maintained in the city and having connection with the sanitary
sewer system of the city for the disposition of wastewater shall have installed
on the waste line from car wash sump a suitable sand and grease trap that will
effectively prevent entrance into the sewer system of sand and grease, and
shall be constructed substantially to conform to state health department design
for the same. The traps shall be skimmed of oil and grease at regular
intervals, and shall be kept in proper operating condition at all times. (1990
Code § 5-305)
11-3-5: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Generally: The code enforcement officer shall make inspection and
testing of all plumbing and sewer connections done within the city and shall
have the right to deputize any person equally qualified to make the actual
inspections and report. He may and shall carry out the performance of this
chapter. The testing of plumbing shall be done by filling all drains with water
to the roof, and such other tests as the code enforcement officer shall deem
necessary. (1990 Code § 5-307; amd. 2006 Code)
   B.   Inspections Required; Number:
      1.   There shall be three (3) plumbing inspections. It is the
responsibility of the owner or plumbing contractor to call for inspections at
the following times and intervals:
         a.   Roughed in;
         b.   Topped out; and
         c.   Final.
      2.   No utility or power company shall supply new water or sewer service
to a building or structure without first being shown a valid plumbing
certificate. (1990 Code § 5-309)
   C.   Fees And Charges: Before an inspection certificate shall be issued for
new installations of plumbing, replacement of existing plumbing, gas fittings
and vented gas appliances, fees and charges shall be paid 1 . (1990 Code § 5-
310)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  11-1-8 of this title.
11-3-6: PLUMBING VEHICLES TO BE IDENTIFIED:
Every truck, car or pickup used in the business of plumbing shall have a sign
on the outside of both of the front doors, bearing the firm's name, address and
public telephone listing. (1990 Code § 5-311)
11-3-7: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter or the code adopted
herein or shall do that which is prohibited or who shall refuse or fail to do
that which is commanded shall be guilty of an offense and shall, upon
conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section
11-1-11 of this title. (1990 Code § 5-312; amd. 2006 Code)
CHAPTER 4
ELECTRICAL CODE AND REGULATIONS
SECTION:
11-4-1: Definitions
11-4-2: Electrical Inspector
11-4-3: Electrical Code Adopted
11-4-4: Compliance With Provisions
11-4-5: Electrical Contractors
11-4-6: Plans And Specifications
11-4-7: Inspections
11-4-8: Electrical Certificates
11-4-9: Interference With Wiring
11-4-10: Nonliability Of City
11-4-11: Violations; Penalty
11-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the following
meanings:
APPRENTICE WIREMAN: Any person who is learning the electric wiring trade and
who is competent to assist, under the supervision of a journeyman wireman, in
the work of installing or repairing electric wiring or installing nonportable
electric fixtures or apparatus.
ELECTRIC WIRING: The installation of electrical raceways, conduits or apparatus
of any kind used, or to be used, in or on any building for the transmission and
distribution of electric current for electric light, heat or power, or
nonportable electrical fixtures and apparatus of any nature to be connected to
light, heat or power service. The words "electric wiring", "electrical
equipment" and "apparatus" shall not be deemed to include or refer to service
lines, apparatus, and equipment for the sale, distribution, and regulation of
electricity and remaining the property of the electric service company or for
telephone, telegraph or other communication purposes, or in connection
therewith.
ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR: Any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business
of installing, repairing or altering electrical wiring, or nonportable electric
fixtures or apparatus in the City, and who has complied with the terms of this
chapter.
ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR: The Chief Electrical Inspector of the City or any of his
duly authorized assistants.
JOURNEYMAN WIREMAN: Any person qualified under the provisions of this chapter
to engage in the installing or repairing of electric wiring or installing
nonportable electric fixtures or apparatus in the City, and who has complied
with the terms of this chapter. (Ord. 2017-265, 4-17-2017, eff. 5-1-2017)
11-4-2: ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment; Qualifications: There is hereby created
the Office of Chief Electrical Inspector. The Chief Electrical Inspector shall
be appointed by the City Manager. He should have a State electrical
contractor's license and shall not be interested, either directly or
indirectly, in any firm or corporation engaged in electrical business within
the City.
   B.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   The electrical inspector shall be charged with the duty of enforcing
the Electrical Code as contained in this chapter.
      2.   The electrical inspector, in the discharge of his duties, may enter
any building or premises at any time during business hours, or at any
reasonable hour upon notification of owner, agent or occupant, and upon the
refusal of any owner, agent or occupant to allow such inspection as required of
the electrical inspector, he shall be cited by law for an offense.
      3.   The electrical inspector shall also institute, by and with the
advice of the City Attorney, such prosecutions as may be necessary against any
violators of any ordinance with the enforcement of which he is charged. (Ord.
2017-265, 4-17-2017, eff. 5-1-2017)
11-4-3: ELECTRICAL CODE ADOPTED:
The Electrical Code is adopted in section
11-2-1 of this title. (Ord. 2017-265, 4-17-2017, eff. 5-1-2017)
11-4-4: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
All electrical materials and equipment and the method of installation thereof
shall be in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. Where no specific
standards are prescribed by this chapter, then such materials, equipment and
installation shall be in conformity with approved standards for safety to
person and property, and compliance with the regulations set forth in the
current National Electrical Code. (Ord. 2017-265, 4-17-2017, eff. 5-1-2017)
11-4-5: ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS 1 :
   A.   State License, City Registration Required: All persons engaged in the
electrical contractor's business shall hold a valid State contractor's license
and shall have such license registered with the City.
   B.   Journeyman Wireman: No person shall work as a journeyman wireman in the
City unless he shall have a valid State journeyman's license and shall have
such license registered with the City.
   C.   Apprentice Electrician: No person shall do any electrical work within
the corporate limits of the City who is not an apprentice having a current
certificate of registration as an apprentice issued by the State and registered
with the City. All apprentices shall carry on their person at all times while
performing electrical work within the City their certificates of registration
(State and City). The Office of Electrical Inspector, upon acceptance for such
registration, shall issue a certificate of registration to each registrant.
Such registration shall authorize such apprentice to do electrical work in the
City, provided such work is done under the direct personal supervision of a
licensed journeyman at all times. Such supervision shall be defined as the
doing of work within sight and audible communication with a journeyman
electrician. No work shall be done by an apprentice when not in the presence of
and under the supervision of a journeyman. No more than three (3) apprentices
shall perform electrical work at the same time under the supervision of one (1)
journeyman electrician.
   D.   Maintenance Electrician: No person shall engage in the occupation of
maintenance electrician without first being registered with the electrical
inspector by owner or owners of the building or buildings, or by the authorized
representative of such owner or owners; such registration showing the name of
the employer, the place of employment, and certifying that the maintenance
electrician named is a regular employee giving his full time to this employer's
service. All maintenance electricians registered in the City shall also be
registered journeymen wiremen.
   E.   Expiration Of Registration; Renewals: All licenses and registrations
provided for herein shall expire on the last day of the contractor's birth
month. A fee will be charged if renewal occurs after the month of the
contractor's birth. (Ord. 2017-265, 4-17-2017, eff. 5-1-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  11-1-8 of this title for fees.
11-4-6: PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
The Office of the Electrical Inspector may require from any electrical
contractor a set of plans and specifications for any proposed electrical job,
in order that the electrical inspector may check such plans and specifications
to determine if the proposed electrical installations will comply with the
ordinances of the City. Approval of plans and specifications for purposes of
issuing a building permit by the City shall not relieve the owner or his agents
of responsibility for errors of any kind in drawings and specifications and for
compliance with applicable codes. (Ord. 2017-265, 4-17-2017, eff. 5-1-2017)
11-4-7: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Inspections Generally; Violations:
      1.   The electrical inspector shall have the power and it shall be his
duty to inspect or reinspect all overhead, underground and interior wires and
apparatus conducting electrical current for any of the purposes set forth in
this chapter. When such conductors or apparatus are found to be unsafe to life
or property, he shall notify the person, firm or corporation owning, using or
operating same, to place them in a safe condition.
      2.   If the owner, user or operator of such defective wiring or equipment
shall refuse or fail to comply with the requirements of the electrical
inspector and shall not correct all defects as directed within a specified
time, it shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to notify, in writing,
the service company, firm or individual furnishing the electric current to
same. Upon receipt of such notice, that service company, firm or individual
furnishing electric current to such defective wiring or equipment shall, within
twenty four (24) hours, disconnect the service or feed wire and cease to supply
current to the defective installation until the defects have been corrected.
      3.   When any portion or all of the wiring in or on any building premises
is ordered changed for any reason, the electrical inspector shall leave
attached to the main switch or service equipment a tag or label showing the
date of the order, and a memorandum of the correction to be made, and the
signature of the authority making the order.
   B.   New Construction:
      1.   Request For Inspection: It shall be the duty of the electrical
contractor and any others holding permits to do electrical work to notify the
Office of the Electrical Inspector as soon as any electrical work is ready for
inspection.
      2.   Inspections Required:
         a.   When any electrical work is done for which a building permit is
required, then the work shall be inspected by the electrical inspector.
         b.   There shall be a rough in and final inspection required and a
temporary service inspection if needed. If such work is not done in such a
manner and with such materials as required by this chapter, the inspector shall
require the work to be redone to comply with this chapter. If the defective
work is not altered to comply, then the electrical inspector may order the
electric utility company to disconnect electrical service to the premises in
which such defective work is situated.
      3.   Time For Inspection: The electrical inspector shall, in all cases,
inspect any and all new electrical wiring within twenty four (24) hours after
receipt of notice from the permit holder that the work is complete and ready
for inspection, the period not to include Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.
      4.   Fees: In order to secure an electrical certificate of approval, any
licensed electrical contractor shall pay the inspection fee required by section
11-1-8 of this title.
   C.   Notice Of Rejection: When a job has been rejected by the Office of the
Electrical Inspector or electrical work condemned by the electrical inspector,
the owner of the premises on which the inspection work is done, or the
electrical contractor doing the electrical work, or both, shall be notified,
specifically setting out what is required to place the electrical portion of
the premises in condition for approval by the electrical inspector.
   D.   Alteration After Inspection: It shall be unlawful for any person to
alter any electric work after its final inspection without obtaining a permit,
the same as required for original installation, repair or alteration. (Ord.
2017-265, 4-17-2017, eff. 5-1-2017)
11-4-8: ELECTRICAL CERTIFICATES:
   A.   Certificate Required: No electric utility company shall connect to any
electrical installation of any kind whatsoever, until furnished with a
certificate of approval providing for such connection duly executed by the
electrical inspector.
   B.   Temporary Certificate: When, for good and sufficient cause, it is
necessary to have electrical energy available at any installation before a
final certificate can be issued, the electrical inspector shall, if the parts
to which the current is to be applied are in safe and satisfactory condition,
issue a temporary certificate. The issuance of such temporary certificate shall
constitute the grant of authority to the electric utility company to provide
electrical energy to the installation. When a temporary service is installed
satisfactorily to the electrical inspector, the electric utility company will
not be permitted to make a connection to permanent service until after a final
inspection certificate has been issued.
   C.   Final Certificate: The electrical certificate will not be issued prior
to the issuance of the plumbing certificate. On the completion of the work
covered by a permit as herein set forth, if such work is performed according to
the provisions of this chapter, the electrical inspector shall issue a
certificate of approval and therein certify that the electrical work is in
accordance with this chapter. Provided, however, that whenever a permit is
issued for any new wiring as an addition to old existing wiring or work, which
existing work does not comply with this chapter, but is of at least no. 14 size
wire on fifteen (15) ampere circuits, then the electrical inspector shall issue
a certificate of approval without requiring the replacement of such existing
wiring and other electrical fixtures, provided the new work for which the
permit was issued complies with this chapter, and provided, further, that the
existing wiring is of sufficient capacity so as not to be dangerous to life or
property. (Ord. 2017-265, 4-17-2017, eff. 5-1-2017)
11-4-9: INTERFERENCE WITH WIRING:
It shall be unlawful for any owner, contractor, or workman, in any manner, to
interfere with any electrical wiring being installed in or on any building. If,
in the course of erection of a building, the wiring is in such position as to
interfere with its re-erection or completion as called for by the plans, notice
shall be immediately given to the person installing the wiring, and the needed
changes shall be made by such person. (Ord. 2017-265, 4-17-2017, eff. 5-1-2017)
11-4-10: NONLIABILITY OF CITY:
Inspections by the City inspectors are made to determine, in general, if the
work is proceeding in accordance with the ordinances of the City. No officer,
agent or employee of the City charged with the enforcement of this chapter
shall render himself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to
persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the
discharge of his duties under this chapter. No person who institutes or assists
in the prosecution of a criminal proceeding under this chapter shall be liable
to damages hereunder unless he acted with actual malice and without reasonable
grounds for believing that the person accused or prosecuted was guilty of an
unlawful act or omission. Any suit brought against any officer, agent, or
employee of the City, as a result of any act required or permitted in the
discharge of his duties under this chapter, shall be defended by the City
Attorney until the final determination of the proceedings therein. (Ord. 2017-
265, 4-17-2017, eff. 5-1-2017)
11-4-11: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY:
   A.   Any person who shall violate any provisions of this chapter, or who
shall do that which is prohibited, or who shall refuse or fail to do that which
is commanded, shall be guilty of an offense and shall, upon conviction thereof,
be punished as provided in section
11-1-11 of this title. Each day of such violation shall be a separate offense.
   B.   Specifically, but not by way of limitation of the general penalty
provision hereof, the following acts are prohibited, and any person convicted
thereof shall be punished as provided in section
11-1-11 of this title. Each day of such violations shall constitute a separate
offense:
      1.   No person, firm or corporation shall do or cause to be done or
permit any of its officers or employees to do any electrical work within the
City without first obtaining a building permit therefor from the Office of the
Electrical Inspector;
      2.   No person, firm or corporation shall cause or permit any employee
who is not a journeyman possessing a certificate of competency issued by the
City electrical inspector or a registered apprentice to do any electrical work
within the City;
      3.   No person, firm or corporation shall do any electrical work within
the City who is not a journeyman with a current certificate of competency as a
journeyman electrician or who is not a registered apprentice as provided in
this chapter;
      4.   No person, firm or corporation shall permit one (1) or more
apprentices to work on any job or project without direct personal supervision
by a journeyman electrician;
      5.   No person, firm or corporation shall permit more than three (3)
apprentices to work under the supervision of one (1) journeyman electrician;
      6.   No apprentice shall do any electrical work within the City except
under the direct supervision of a journeyman electrician;
      7.   No journeyman electrician or apprentice shall perform electrical
work within the City unless he shall have on his person a current journeyman's
certificate of competency or apprentice's certificate of registration, and no
journeyman or apprentice, while performing electrical work within the City,
shall refuse to display his certificate of registration upon request of the
electrical inspector, an assistant electrical inspector or a police officer of
the City; and
      8.   No apprentice shall do any electrical work within the City in
conjunction with more than two (2) such apprentices under the supervision of
the same journeyman electrician. (Ord. 2017-265, 4-17-2017, eff. 5-1-2017)
CHAPTER 5
MECHANICAL CODE AND REGULATIONS
SECTION:
11-5-1: Mechanical Code
11-5-2: State License And City Registration Required
11-5-3: Registration Fees
11-5-4: Suspension Or Revocation Of Registration
11-5-1: MECHANICAL CODE:
   A.   Code And State Act Adopted: The city council hereby adopts the
international mechanical code, as shown in section
11-2-1 of this title, and the state mechanical licensing act, and all
subsequent editions or amendments to same, as the "Mechanical Code Of The City
Of Lone Grove, Oklahoma". The city council hereby ratifies, adopts, and
incorporates any and all provisions, sections, definitions, requirements,
specifications, or standards contained in the booklets or publications
described in this subsection as if set out herein. (1990 Code §§ 5-1001, 5-
1002; amd. 2006 Code; Ord. 2012-245, 10-22-2012, eff. 11-1-2012)
   B.   Copies On File: The books or manuals described in this section shall be
purchased by the city clerk and shall be available for inspection at all
reasonable times in the clerk's office by an interested or affected person.
(1990 Code § 5-1006)
11-5-2: STATE LICENSE AND CITY REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
Before any person, firm, entity, or corporation engages in the installation of
gas piping or mechanical systems within the city limits, the person, firm,
entity, or corporation must possess a current contractor, journeyman, or
apprentice license, in good standing, as required by the statutes of the state.
The license must be registered with the code enforcement officer prior to end
of birth month and shall be on file with the code enforcement officer prior to
the commencement of gas piping or mechanical system installation. (1990 Code §
5-1003; amd. 2006 Code)
11-5-3: REGISTRATION FEES:
The code enforcement officer shall collect the fees established in section
11-1-8 of this title for registration of the licenses described in section
11-5-2 of this chapter. (1990 Code § 5-1004; amd. Ord. 210, 10-20-2003, eff.
11-21-2003; 2006 Code)
11-5-4: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF REGISTRATION:
Any person, firm, entity, or corporation holding any of the licenses described
herein, who shall have the license(s) revoked or suspended by any agency of the
state, or any federal agency, shall suffer the same revocation or suspension
with the city of the city registration concurrent with the period of revocation
or suspension period prescribed by the applicable state or federal agency.
(1990 Code § 5-1005; amd. 2006 Code)
CHAPTER 6
GAS CODE AND REGULATIONS
SECTION:
11-6-1: Fuel Gas Code Adopted
11-6-2: Liquefied Petroleum Gas
11-6-3: Natural Gas Connections
11-6-1: FUEL GAS CODE ADOPTED:
The fuel gas code is adopted in section
11-2-1 of this title. (Ord. 2012-245, 10-22-2012, eff. 11-1-2012)
11-6-2: LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS 1 :
It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to manufacture, fabricate,
assemble, install, or repair any system, container, apparatus, or appliance to
be used for the transportation, storage, dispensing, or utilization of
liquefied petroleum gas, or to transport, handle, or store such gas, unless
