Sporting goods sales.
Storage warehouse.
Supermarket.
Tailor shop.
Tavern.
Theater (indoor).
Toy store.
Variety store.
Wholesale distributing center.
   D.   Any other store or shop for retail trade or for rendering personal,
professional, or business service which does not produce more noise, odor,
dust, vibration, blast or traffic than those enumerated above.
   E.   Buildings, structures and uses accessory and customarily incidental to
any of the above uses; provided, that there shall be no manufacture, processing
or compounding of products other than such as are customarily incidental and
essential to retail establishments.
   F.   Displays of merchandise held for sale outside stores or buildings shall
be allowed. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982; amd. Ord. 193, 1-17-2000, eff. 2-16-2000; 2006
Code; Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
12-7C-3: SPECIAL USES:
Special use permits shall be authorized in the C-3 General Commercial District
after having been approved by the City Council by a minimum of four (4)
affirmative votes, after compliance with the provisions of section
12-2-3 of this title. (Ord. 141, 1-16-1995, eff. 3-18-1995)
12-7C-4: AREA AND YARDS:
The area requirements for dwellings and buildings accessory thereto shall be
the same as the area requirements for the R-5 High Density Residential District
(section
12-6E-4 of this title). The following requirements shall apply to all other
uses permitted in this district, except as provided in section
12-4-2 of this title:
   A.   Front Yard: There are no specific front yard requirements for uses
other than dwellings.
   B.   Side Yard: On the side of a lot adjoining a Residential District, there
shall be a side yard of not less than ten feet (10'). Whenever the rear lot
line of a corner lot abuts a Residential District, the side yard adjacent to
the street shall not be less than fifteen feet (15') in width. In all other
cases, no side yard shall be required.
   C.   Rear Yard:
      1.   Whenever the rear lot line abuts a Residential District, there shall
be provided a rear yard of not less than twenty feet (20').
      2.   Where a commercial building is to be serviced from the rear, there
shall be provided an alleyway, service court, rear yard, or combination thereof
of not less than thirty feet (30') in width. In all other cases, no rear yard
is required.
   D.   Off Street Parking: Buildings shall be provided with a yard area
adequate to meet the off street parking requirements set forth in chapter 12 of
this title.
   E.   Abutting Residential District: Whenever any Commercial District or
parking lot or parking area is established so as to abut the side or rear line
of a lot in a Residential District, an opaque, ornamental fence or wall not
less than five feet (5') high and not more than six feet (6') high shall be
constructed and maintained in good condition along said side or rear lot line
up to, but not beyond, the abutting residential building setback line, except
when the front yard is used for off street parking, then the provisions of
chapter 12 of this title, pertaining to off street parking lots, shall apply.
In addition, the lighting, including any permitted illuminated sign, shall be
arranged so that there will be no annoying glare directed or reflected toward
residential buildings in a Residential District. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-7C-5: BUILDING HEIGHT:
There are no specific height regulations established for uses permitted in this
district, except as otherwise provided in section
12-4-3 of this title. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-7C-6: EXTERIOR REQUIREMENTS:
All dwellings, buildings/structures and use accessory buildings/structures
erected after the effective date hereof shall have veneer finish on the
exterior of the entrance side and all other exterior sides which face a public
right-of-way. (Ord. 2016-262, 4-18-2016, eff. 6-18-2016)
ARTICLE D.  C-4 HIGHWAY COMMERCIAL DISTRICT
SECTION:
12-7D-1: Intent And Purpose
12-7D-2: Permitted Uses And Conditions
12-7D-3: Special Uses
12-7D-4: Area And Yards
12-7D-5: Building Height
12-7D-6: Exterior Requirements
12-7D-7: Off Premises Advertising Signs
12-7D-1: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
The C-4 Highway Commercial District is intended to provide a location for the
limited amount of merchandise, equipment, and material being offered for retail
sale that, because of the type of material or transportation requirements, are
suitable for display and storage outside the confines of an enclosed building
or which require easy and direct access by the traveling public. There will be
more assembly of equipment and incidental activity than would prevail in the
General Commercial District. Persons of the community and the surrounding trade
territory will require direct access. However, the concentration of shoppers
will be much smaller and visits less frequent than in the General Commercial
District. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-7D-2: PERMITTED USES AND CONDITIONS:
Property and buildings in a C-4 Highway Commercial District shall be used only
for the following purposes:
   A.   Any use permitted in a C-3 General Commercial District (section
12-7C-2 of this chapter).
   B.   Any of the following uses:
Advertising signs.
Automobile court or tourist court.
Automobile sales and service.
Automobile service station.
Boat sales.
Car wash.
Farm implements and machinery sales and service.
Feed and fuel store.
Machinery sales and services.
Medical marijuana dispensary.
Metal and wood fencing, ornamental grillwork and decorative wrought ironwork
and play equipment sales.
Mobile home and camper sales.
Monument sales.
Motel.
Prefabricated house sales.
Restaurant, drive-in.
Theater, drive-in.
Trailers for hauling, rental and sales.
Truck sales and service.
   C.   The uses listed under subsection B of this section shall comply with
the following provisions:
      1.   All open storage and display of merchandise, material, and equipment
shall be so screened by ornamental fencing that it cannot be seen by a person
standing on ground level in a Residential District when located to the side or
rear of the lot on which said open storage or display occurs; provided,
however, that screening shall not be required in excess of seven feet (7') in
height. Merchandise and materials which are not completely assembled or which
are not immediately and actively being offered for sale shall, in addition to
complying with the screening requirements of this subsection C1, be so screened
by ornamental fences or by permanent buildings that it cannot be seen from a
public street.
      2.   All yards unoccupied with buildings or merchandise or used as
trafficways shall be landscaped with grass and shrubs and maintained in good
condition the year round.
      3.   All of the lot used for the parking of vehicles, for the storage and
display of merchandise and all driveways used for vehicle ingress and egress
shall be paved with a sealed surface pavement and maintained in such a manner
that no dust will be produced by continued use.
      4.   All servicing of vehicles and assembly of equipment carried on as an
incidental part of the sales operation shall be conducted within a completely
enclosed building.
      5.   Driveways used for ingress and egress shall not exceed twenty five
feet (25') in width, exclusive of curb returns.
      6.   Outdoor lighting, when provided, shall have an arrangement of
reflectors and an intensity of lighting which will not interfere with adjacent
land uses or the use of adjacent streets, and shall not be of a flashing or
intermittent type. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982; amd. Ord. 2006-218, 10-16-2006, eff.
11-16-2006; Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
12-7D-3: SPECIAL USES:
Special use permits shall be authorized in the C-4 Highway Commercial District
after having been approved by the City Council by a minimum of four (4)
affirmative votes, after compliance with the provisions of section
12-2-3 of this title. (Ord. 141, 1-16-1995, eff. 3-18-1995)
12-7D-4: AREA AND YARDS:
The area requirements for dwellings and buildings accessory thereto shall be
the same as the area requirements for the R-5 High Density Residential District
(section
12-6E-4 of this title). The following requirements shall apply to all other
uses permitted in this district, except as provided in section
12-4-2 of this title:
   A.   Front Yard: All buildings shall set back from the street right-of-way
line to provide a front yard having not less than twenty five feet (25').
   B.   Side Yard: On the side of a lot adjoining a Residential District, there
shall be a side yard of not less than ten feet (10'). Whenever the rear lot
line of a corner lot abuts a Residential District, the side yard adjacent to
the street shall not be less than fifteen feet (15') in width. In all other
cases, no side yard shall be required.
   C.   Rear Yard:
      1.   Whenever the rear lot line abuts a Residential District, there shall
be provided a rear yard of not less than twenty feet (20').
      2.   Where a commercial building is to be serviced from the rear, there
shall be provided an alleyway, service court, rear yard, or combination thereof
of not less than thirty feet (30') in width. In all other cases, no rear yard
is required.
   D.   Off Street Parking: Buildings shall be provided with a yard area
adequate to meet the off street parking requirements set forth in chapter 12 of
this title.
   E.   Abutting Residential District: Whenever any Commercial District or
parking lot or parking area is established so as to abut the side or rear line
of a lot in a Residential District, an opaque, ornamental fence or wall, not
less than five feet (5') high and not more than six feet (6') high, shall be
constructed and maintained in good condition along said side or rear lot line
up to, but not beyond, the abutting residential setback building line, except
where the front yard is used for off street parking, then the provisions of
chapter 12 of this title, pertaining to off street parking lots, shall apply.
In addition, the lighting, including any permitted illuminated sign, shall be
arranged so that there will be no annoying glare directed or reflected toward
residential buildings in a Residential District. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-7D-5: BUILDING HEIGHT:
There are no specific height regulations established for uses permitted in this
district, except as otherwise provided for in section
12-4-3 of this title. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-7D-6: EXTERIOR REQUIREMENTS:
All dwellings, buildings/structures and use accessory buildings/structures
erected after the effective date hereof shall have veneer finish on the
exterior of the entrance side and all other exterior sides which face a public
right-of-way. (Ord. 2016-262, 4-18-2016, eff. 6-18-2016)
12-7D-7: OFF PREMISES ADVERTISING SIGNS:
   A.   Off premises advertising sign restrictions are as follows:
      1.   The area of any given sign shall not exceed three hundred (300)
square feet and no more than two (2) parallel signs will be allowed per
structure.
      2.   An off premises sign shall not be located within one thousand feet
(1,000') of another off premises sign on either side of the street, roadway or
highway.
      3.   All portions of the sign shall be located a minimum of ten feet
(10') from all property lines, except when adjoining a Residential District
where the setback from the property lines shall be a minimum of twenty five
feet (25').
      4.   The billboard sign shall not be allowed or located within any clear
sight triangle.
      5.   The area of the sign or sign area is defined by the total area of
the message surfaces of a sign. If a sign has more than one message surface,
the area of the sign shall be the sum of the areas of all message surfaces.
      6.   All off premises or off site signs must comply with Oklahoma State
Statutes and agency regulations and be properly permitted as such by Municipal
and State agencies.
      7.   Off premises signs to include advertising billboards will be
prohibited from the Highway 70 Downtown District area between Newport Road
going east to Brock Road on both sides of the road or highway.
      8.   On site signs or on premises signs will continue to be allowed
according to this Code and are not affected by these restrictions.
      9.   All signs shall be maintained in a safe, presentable and good
structural condition at all times. The Code Enforcement Officer or his/her
authorized representative shall inspect and shall have the authority to order
the painting, repair, alteration or removal of a sign which shall constitute a
blight, hazard to safety, health or public welfare by reason of inadequate
maintenance, dilapidation or obsolescence.
      10.   An abandoned sign is defined as: a) a sign that identifies an
establishment, goods or services that are no longer provided on the premises
where the sign is located; b) a sign that identifies a time or event or purpose
that has passed or no longer is applicable; c) a changeable message sign which
can no longer be read due to missing letters or graphics; d) a sign that has
not been properly maintained and poses a risk to the community. Any sign that
meets the requirement for an abandoned sign and where the condition has existed
for a period of more than one hundred eighty (180) days, and where the sign is
also nonconforming, shall be removed by the property owner at the request or
demand of the Code Enforcement Officer (or by the City of Lone Grove at the
owner's expense) within five (5) days following the expiration of the one
hundred eighty (180) day period. (Ord. 2006-218, 10-16-2006, eff. 11-16-2006;
amd. Ord. 2016-262, 4-18-2016, eff. 6-18-2016)
ARTICLE E.  C-5 PLANNED SHOPPING CENTER COMMERCIAL DISTRICT
SECTION:
12-7E-1: Intent And Purpose
12-7E-2: Permitted Uses
12-7E-3: Special Uses
12-7E-4: Area And Yards
12-7E-5: Building Height
12-7E-6: Exterior Requirements
12-7E-7: Common Parking Facilities
12-7E-8: Procedures For Rezoning To Shopping Center District
12-7E-1: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
The C-5 planned shopping center commercial district is intended for a unified
grouping, in one or more buildings, of retail shops and stores that provide for
the regular needs and are for the convenience of the people residing in the
community and the surrounding trade region. It is intended that the planned
shopping center be developed as a unit, with adequate off street parking space
for customers and employees, and with appropriate landscaping and screening
materials. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982; amd. 2006 Code)
12-7E-2: PERMITTED USES:
Property and buildings in a C-5 planned shopping center commercial district
shall be used only for the uses enumerated in this section; provided, however,
that these uses shall be located in a unified shopping center which shall have
not less than five (5) shops and stores:
   A.   Any of the following uses may be permitted:
Antique shop.
Apparel store, family, children, men or women.
Appliance store.
Artist supplies.
Automobile parking lot.
Bakery goods store.
Bank.
Barbershop.
Beauty shop.
Book or stationery store.
Camera shop.
Candy store.
Catering establishment.
Cleaning and pressing collection station.
Curio shop.
Dairy products or ice cream store.
Delicatessen.
Drugstore or fountain.
Dry goods store.
Florist shop.
Furniture store.
Gift shop.
Grocery store.
Hardware store.
Help yourself laundry.
Jewelry store.
Meat market.
Medical facility.
Medical marijuana dispensary.
Music store.
Newspaper or magazine sales.
Notions store.
Office supply store.
Optometrist sales and service.
Paint and decorating shop.
Pharmacy.
Photographer studio.
Radio and television sales and service.
Restaurant.
Sewing machine sales and service.
Shoe store or repair shop.
Specialty shop.
Sporting goods sales.
Supermarket.
Tailor shop.
Toy store.
Variety store.
   B.   Office uses; provided, however, that the total gross floor area of all
office uses, exclusive of those listed in subsection A of this section, shall
not exceed twenty percent (20%) of the gross floor area of the shopping center.
   C.   Automobile service station which shall be planned as an integral part
of the center and constructed at the time of construction of the center.
   D.   Advertising signs relating to the shopping center, the stores and shops
therein and products sold therein. All advertising signs and structures shall
be designed as an integral part of the shopping center development and shall be
harmonious with the other design features of the center.
   E.   Accessory buildings and uses customarily incidental to the above uses.
(Ord. 86, 2-16-1982; amd. 2006 Code; Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
12-7E-3: SPECIAL USES:
Special use permits shall be authorized in the C-5 Planned Shopping Center
Commercial District after having been approved by the City Council by a minimum
of four (4) affirmative votes, after compliance with the provisions of section
12-2-3 of this title. (Ord. 141, 1-16-1995, eff. 3-18-1995)
12-7E-4: AREA AND YARDS:
   A.   Yards: It is intended that the grouping of the buildings and parking
areas be designed to protect, insofar as possible, adjacent residential areas,
and that ornamental screening from noise and light be provided where necessary;
provided, however, that in no case shall the design of the shopping center
provide less than the following standards:
      1.   All buildings shall set back from all street right-of-way lines not
less than twenty five feet (25').
      2.   On any side of a lot adjoining a Residential District, there shall
be a yard of not less than twenty five feet (25').
      3.   There shall be a rear yard, alley, service court, or combination
thereof, of not less than thirty feet (30') in width, and all of the service
area of all buildings shall be completely screened from public view with
permanent ornamental screening materials.
      4.   Whenever any commercial district or parking lot or parking area is
established so as to abut the side or rear line of a lot in a residential
district, an opaque, ornamental fence or wall not less than five feet (5') high
and not more than six feet (6') high shall be constructed and maintained in
good condition along said side or rear lot line up to, but not beyond, the
abutting residential building setback line, except when the front yard is used
for off street parking, then the provisions of chapter 12 of this title,
pertaining to off street parking lots, shall apply. In addition, the lighting,
including any permitted illuminated sign, shall be arranged so that there will
be no annoying glare directed or reflected toward residential buildings in a
residential district.
   B.   Intensity Of Use: The parcel of land on which a planned shopping center
is located shall not be less than three (3) acres in area.
   C.   Lot Coverage: Buildings shall not cover more than twenty percent (20%)
of the site on which the shopping center is located. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-7E-5: BUILDING HEIGHT:
No building shall exceed two and one-half (21/2) stories, or thirty five feet
(35') in height, except as provided in section
12-4-3 of this title. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-7E-6: EXTERIOR REQUIREMENTS:
All dwellings, buildings/structures and use accessory buildings/structures
erected after the effective date hereof shall have veneer finish on the
exterior of the entrance side and all other exterior sides which face a public
right of way. (Ord. 2016-262, 4-18-2016, eff. 6-18-2016)
12-7E-7: COMMON PARKING FACILITIES:
Off street parking requirements set forth in chapter 12 of this title may be
complied with by providing a permanent common off street parking facility for
all of the uses within the shopping center; provided, that the lot contains the
requisite number of spaces for each use. The total number of spaces provided
shall not be less than the sum of the individual requirements; provided,
however, that in no case shall the amount of off street parking area, including
driveways required for ingress and egress and circulation, be less than two and
one-half (21/2) times the gross floor area of the shopping center. (Ord. 86, 2-
16-1982; amd. Ord. 2016-262, 4-18-2016, eff. 6-18-2016)
12-7E-8: PROCEDURES FOR REZONING TO SHOPPING CENTER DISTRICT:
An application for rezoning for a shopping center shall include the following,
in addition to the administrative requirements set forth in chapter 2 of this
title:
   A.   Site Development Plans:
      1.   The developer shall submit site development plans of the proposed
development which shall be in adequate detail to determine compliance with the
provisions of this article; and which shall show the arrangement of the
buildings, design, and circulation pattern of the off street parking area,
landscaped yards, ornamental screening, service courts, and utility and
drainage easements and facilities; and the relationship of the shopping center
development to adjacent areas which it may affect.
      2.   Evidence that indicates to the satisfaction of the planning
commission the ability and intent of the developer to carry out the development
of the shopping center in accordance with the plans submitted as required in
subsection A1 of this section.
   B.   Development Procedure: The developer shall obtain a building permit for
the shopping center in accordance with the requirements and procedure of
section
12-2-2 of this title, and shall begin construction of the shopping center
within two (2) years after the effective date of rezoning for the shopping
center, and shall make a reasonable and continuous progress toward completion.
If the shopping center is not under construction within two (2) years after the
effective date of the shopping center rezoning, the planning commission shall
review the status of the development, and if it shall find that the developer
cannot proceed immediately with the development in conformity with the
requirements of this article, the commission shall recommend to the city
council the appropriate action and zoning classification to implement and be
consistent with the comprehensive plan.
   C.   Review Of Plan Change: Any substantial deviation from the plat or
building plans submitted at the time of rezoning shall constitute a violation
of the building permit authorizing construction of the shopping center.
Substantial changes in plans shall be resubmitted to the planning commission to
ensure compliance with the requirements and purpose and intent of this article,
and no building permit shall be issued for any construction which is not in
substantial conformity with the approved plan. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982; amd. Ord.
2016-262, 4-18-2016, eff. 6-18-2016)
CHAPTER 8
INDUSTRIAL DISTRICTS
ARTICLE A.  I-1 LIGHT INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT
SECTION:
12-8A-1: Intent And Purpose
12-8A-2: Permitted Uses And Conditions
12-8A-3: Special Uses
12-8A-4: Area And Yards
12-8A-5: Building Height
12-8A-6: Off Premises Advertising Signs
12-8A-1: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
The I-1 Light Industrial District is intended primarily for production and
assembly plants that are conducted so the noise, odor, dust, and glare of each
operation is completely confined within an enclosed building, and for
warehousing, wholesale, and service uses. These industries may require direct
access to rail, air, or street transportation routes. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-8A-2: PERMITTED USES AND CONDITIONS:
Property and buildings in an I-1 Light Industrial District shall be used only
for the following purposes:
   A.   Any use, except dwellings, permitted in the C-4 Highway Commercial
District (section
12-7D-2 of this title). No dwelling use, except sleeping facilities required by
caretakers or night watchmen employed on the premises, shall be permitted in an
I-1 Light Industrial District.
   B.   Any of the following uses:
Advertising signs and structures.
Book bindery.
Bottling works.
Building material sales yard and lumberyard, including the sale of rock, sand,
gravel, and the like as an incidental part of the main business, but not
including a concrete batch plant or transit mix plant.
Candy manufacturing.
Contractor's equipment storage yard or plant, or rental of equipment commonly
used by contractors.
Electrical equipment assembly.
Electronic equipment assembly and manufacture.
Engraving plant.
Food products processing and packing.
Freighting or trucking yard or terminal.
Furniture manufacturing.
Garment manufacturing.
Instrument and meter manufacturing.
Jewelry and watch manufacturing.
   Laboratories, experimental.
Leather goods fabrication.
Medical marijuana grower, manufacturer, storage or processor.
Oil field equipment storage yard.
Outdoor advertising signs.
Paper products manufacturing.
Public utility service yard or electrical receiving or transforming station.
Sale barn.
Sporting goods manufacturing.
   C.   The following uses, when conducted within a completely enclosed
building:
      1.   The manufacture, compounding, processing, packaging, or treatment of
such products as bakery goods, candy, cosmetics, dairy products, drugs,
perfumes, pharmaceuticals, perfumed toilet soap, toiletries, and food products.
      2.   The manufacture, compounding, assembling, or treatment of articles
or merchandise from the following previously prepared materials: bone,
cellophane, canvas, cloth, cork, feathers, felt, fiber, fur, glass, hair, horn,
leather, paper, plastics, precious or semiprecious metals or stone, shell,
textiles, tobacco, wood, yarn, and paint not employing a boiling process.
      3.   The manufacture of pottery and figurines or other similar ceramic
products, using only previously pulverized clay and kilns fired only by
electricity or gas.
      4.   The manufacture and maintenance of electric and neon signs,
commercial advertising structures, light sheet metal products, including
heating and ventilating ducts and equipment, cornices, eaves, and the like.
      5.   Manufacture of musical instruments, toys, novelties, and rubber and
metal stamps.
      6.   Automobile assembling, painting, upholstering, rebuilding,
reconditioning, and body and fender works, truck repairing and overhauling,
tire retreading or recapping, and battery manufacturing.
      7.   Blacksmith shop and machine shop, excluding punch presses over
twenty (20) tons' rated capacity, drop hammers, and automatic screw machines.
      8.   Foundry casting lightweight nonferrous metal not causing noxious
fumes or odors.
      9.   Assembly of electrical appliances, electrical instruments and
devices, radios and phonographs, including the manufacture of small parts only,
such as coils, condensers, transformers, crystal holders, and the like.
      10.   Wholesale storage or manufacture of alcoholic beverages.
   D.   Buildings, structures, and uses accessory and customarily incidental to
any of the above uses.
   E.   The uses permitted under this section shall be conducted in such a
manner that no noxious odor, fumes, or dust will be emitted beyond the property
line of the lot on which the use is located.
   F.   No article or material permitted in this district shall be kept,
stored, or displayed outside the confines of a building unless it be so
screened by fences, walls, or planting that it cannot be seen from adjoining
public streets or adjacent lots when viewed by a person standing on ground
level. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982; amd. 2006 Code; Ord. 2018-274, 11-19-2018)
12-8A-3: SPECIAL USES:
Special use permits shall be authorized in the I-1 Light Industrial District
after having been approved by the City Council by a minimum of four (4)
affirmative votes, after compliance with the provisions of section
12-2-3 of this title. (Ord. 141, 1-16-1995, eff. 3-18-1995)
12-8A-4: AREA AND YARDS:
All uses permitted in this district shall comply with the following yard
requirements, except as provided in section
12-4-2 of this title:
   A.   Front Yard: All buildings shall set back from the street right-of-way
line to provide a front yard having not less than twenty five feet (25') in
depth.
   B.   Side Yard: No building shall be located closer than twenty five feet
(25') to a side lot line; except, that when the side of a lot abuts a
Residential District, there shall be provided a side yard of not less than
fifty feet (50').
   C.   Rear Yard: No building shall be located closer than twenty five feet
(25') to the rear lot line; except, that when the rear of a lot abuts a
Residential District, there shall be provided a rear yard of not less than
fifty feet (50').
   D.   Landscaping: All yard areas required under this section and other yards
and open spaces existing around buildings shall be landscaped and maintained in
a neat condition.
   E.   Abutting Residential District: Whenever any Industrial District or
parking lot or parking area is established so as to abut the side or rear line
of a lot in a Residential District, an opaque, ornamental fence or wall not
less than five feet (5') high and not more than six feet (6') high shall be
constructed and maintained in good condition along said side or rear lot line
up to, but not beyond, the abutting residential setback building line, except
where the front yard is used for off street parking, then the provisions of
chapter 12 of this title, pertaining to off street parking lots, shall apply.
In addition, the lighting, including any permitted illuminated sign, shall be
arranged so that there will be no annoying glare directed or reflected toward
residential buildings in a Residential District.
   F.   Lot Coverage: Main and accessory buildings and off street parking and
loading facilities shall not cover more than eighty percent (80%) of the lot
area. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-8A-5: BUILDING HEIGHT:
No building or structure shall exceed forty five feet (45') in height, except
as provided in section
12-4-3 of this title. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-8A-6: OFF PREMISES ADVERTISING SIGNS:
   A.   Off premises advertising sign restrictions are as follows:
      1.   The area of any given sign shall not exceed three hundred (300)
square feet and no more than two (2) parallel signs will be allowed per
structure.
      2.   An off premises sign shall not be located within one thousand feet
(1,000') of another off premises sign on either side of the street, roadway or
highway.
      3.   All portions of the sign shall be located a minimum of ten feet
(10') from all property lines, except when adjoining a residential district
where the setback from the property lines shall be a minimum of twenty five
feet (25').
      4.   The proposed billboard sign shall not be allowed or located within
any clear sight triangle.
      5.   The area of the sign or sign area is defined by the total area of
the message surfaces of a sign. If a sign has more than one message surface,
the area of the sign shall be the sum of the areas of all message surfaces.
      6.   All off premises or off site signs must comply with Oklahoma State
law and be properly permitted as such.
      7.   Off premises signs to include advertising billboards will be
prohibited from the U.S. Highway 70 Downtown District area between Newport Road
going east to Brock Road on both sides of the road or highway.
      8.   On site signs or on premises signs will continue to be allowed
according to the existing Lone Grove code of ordinances and are not affected by
these restrictions.
      9.   All signs shall be maintained in a safe, presentable and good
structural condition at all times. The Code Enforcement Officer or his/her
authorized representative shall inspect and shall have the authority to order
the painting, repair, alteration or removal of a sign which shall constitute a
blight, hazard to safety, health or public welfare by reason of inadequate
maintenance, dilapidation or obsolescence.
      10.   An abandoned sign is defined as: a) a sign that identifies an
establishment, goods or services that are no longer provided on the premises
where the sign is located; b) a sign that identifies a time or event or purpose
that has passed or no longer is applicable; c) a changeable message sign which
can no longer be read due to missing letters or graphics; d) a sign that has
not been properly maintained and poses a risk to the community. Any sign that
meets the requirement for an abandoned sign and where the condition has existed
for a period of more than one hundred eighty (180) days, and where the sign is
also nonconforming, shall be removed by the property owner at the request of
the Code Enforcement Officer (or by the City of Lone Grove at the owner's
expense if the Code Enforcement Officer's demand or request is ignored or not
complied with) within five (5) days following the expiration of the one hundred
eighty (180) day period. (Ord. 2006-218, 10-16-2006, eff. 11-16-2006)
ARTICLE B.  I-2 HEAVY INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT
SECTION:
12-8B-1: Intent And Purpose
12-8B-2: Permitted And Prohibited Uses
12-8B-3: Special Uses
12-8B-4: Area And Yards
12-8B-5: Building Height
12-8B-1: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
The I-2 heavy industrial district is intended to provide for heavy industrial
uses and other uses not otherwise provided for in the districts established by
this title. The intensity of uses permitted in this district makes it desirable
that they be located downwind and separated from residential and commercial
uses wherever possible. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-8B-2: PERMITTED AND PROHIBITED USES:
Property and buildings in an I-2 heavy industrial district may be used for any
use except the following:
   A.   All residential uses except sleeping facilities required by night
watchmen and caretakers employed upon the premises.
   B.   All uses not complying with this title, or any other county, state, or
federal regulation or law.
   C.   All of the following uses until they have been studied by the planning
commission and have received the express approval of the city council. The city
council may require approval of the county health department, the state fire
marshal, and other state and county regulating agencies, and may attach to the
approval specific restrictions designed to protect the public welfare.
Acid manufacture.
Cement, lime, gypsum, or plaster of Paris manufacture.
Explosives, manufacture or wholesale storage.
Gas manufacture.
Petroleum or its products, refining of.
Wholesale or bulk storage of gasoline, propane, or butane or other petroleum
products.
   D.   Property and buildings in an I-2 heavy industrial district, when used
for the following purposes, shall have the uses thereon conducted in such a
manner that all operation, display, or storage of material or equipment is so
screened by ornamental fences or walls that it cannot be seen from a public
street:
Automobile salvage or junkyard.
Building materials salvage yard.
Scrap metal storage yard.
Any other kind of junk or salvage yard. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982; amd. 2006 Code)
12-8B-3: SPECIAL USES:
Special use permits shall be authorized in the I-2 heavy industrial district
after having been approved by the city council by a minimum of four (4)
affirmative votes, after compliance with the provisions of section
12-2-3 of this title. (Ord. 141, 1-16-1995, eff. 3-18-1995)
12-8B-4: AREA AND YARDS:
All uses permitted in this district shall comply with the following area and
yard requirements, except as provided in section
12-4-2 of this title: (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982; amd. 2006 Code)
   A.   Front Yard: There are no specific front yard requirements established
for uses permitted in this district.
   B.   Side Yard: When the side of a lot abuts a residential district, there
shall be provided a side yard of not less than fifty feet (50'). In all other
cases, no side yard is required.
   C.   Rear Yard:
      1.   When the rear of a lot abuts a residential district, there shall be
provided a rear yard of not less than fifty feet (50').
      2.   Where a building is to be serviced from the rear, there shall be
provided an alleyway, service court, rear yard or combination thereof of not
less than thirty feet (30') in width or of adequate area and width to provide
for maneuver of service vehicles, whichever is greater. In all other cases, no
rear yard is required.
   D.   Off Street Parking: Buildings shall be provided with a yard area
adequate to meet the off street parking requirements set forth in chapter 12 of
this title.
   E.   Abutting Residential District: Whenever any industrial district or
parking lot or parking area is established so as to abut the side or rear line
of a lot in a residential district, an opaque, ornamental fence or wall not
less than five feet (5') high and not more than six feet (6') high shall be
constructed and maintained in good condition along said side or rear lot line
up to, but not beyond, the abutting residential setback building line, except
where the front yard is used for off street parking, then the provisions in
chapter 12 of this title, pertaining to off street parking lots, shall apply.
In addition, the lighting, including any permitted illuminated sign, shall be
arranged so that there will be no annoying glare directed or reflected toward
residential buildings in a residential district. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-8B-5: BUILDING HEIGHT:
Where a lot adjoins a residential district, the building shall not exceed forty
five feet (45') in height, unless it is set back one foot (1') from all front,
side and rear building lines for each foot of additional height above forty
five feet (45'), except as provided in section
12-4-3 of this title. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
CHAPTER 9
F FLOODPLAIN DISTRICT 1
SECTION:
12-9-1: Intent And Purpose
12-9-2: Permitted Uses
12-9-3: Special Uses
 
Notes
1 1. See also title 14, chapter 1 of this code.
12-9-1: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
The F floodplain district is intended to comprise those areas which are subject
to periodic or occasional inundation and, therefore, are unsuited for all
residential uses and the usual commercial and industrial uses. (Ord. 86, 2-16-
1982)
12-9-2: PERMITTED USES:
Property and buildings in the F floodplain district shall be used only for the
following purposes:
   A.   The growing of agricultural crops and nursery stock, and gardening.
   B.   The keeping of agricultural livestock in accordance with the municipal
ordinances relating thereto.
   C.   Public recreation not involving buildings. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-9-3: SPECIAL USES:
Special use permits shall be authorized in the F floodplain district after
having been approved by the city council by a minimum of four (4) affirmative
votes, after compliance with the provisions of section
12-2-3 of this title. (Ord. 141, 1-16-1995, eff. 3-18-1995)
CHAPTER 10
EC ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION DISTRICT
SECTION:
12-10-1: Intent And Purpose
12-10-2: Permitted Uses
12-10-3: Special Uses
12-10-4: Lot Area And Yards
12-10-5: Building Height
12-10-1: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
The EC environment conservation district is intended to provide for the
protection and preservation of environmentally sensitive lands incapable of
accommodating development of an urban character without experiencing any
adverse impacts as a result. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-10-2: PERMITTED USES:
Property and buildings in the EC environmental conservation district shall be
used only for the following purposes:
   A.   The growing of agricultural crops, nursery stock, and gardening.
   B.   The raising of farm animals in accordance with city ordinances.
   C.   Advertising sign. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-10-3: SPECIAL USES:
Special use permits shall be authorized in the EC environmental conservation
district after having been approved by the city council by a minimum of four
(4) affirmative votes, after compliance with the provisions of section
12-2-3 of this title. (Ord. 141, 1-16-1995, eff. 3-18-1995)
12-10-4: LOT AREA AND YARDS:
All buildings shall be set back from street right of way and lot lines to
comply with the following lot area and/or yard requirements, except as provided
in section
12-4-2 of this title: (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982; amd. 2006 Code)
   A.   Front Yard: All buildings shall be set back from the street right of
way line to provide a front yard having not less than twenty five feet (25') in
depth.
   B.   Side Yard: A side yard of not less than fifteen feet (15') shall be
provided for all lots upon which a building is located.
   C.   Rear Yard: A rear yard of not less than twenty feet (20') shall be
provided for all lots upon which a building is located.
   D.   Lot Width: There shall be a minimum lot width for all buildings of not
less than one hundred feet (100').
   E.   Intensity Of Use: For each main building and buildings accessory
thereto, there shall be a lot area of not less than ten (10) acres.
   F.   Lot Coverage: Main and accessory buildings shall not cover more than
five percent (5%) of the lot area. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-10-5: BUILDING HEIGHT:
No building shall exceed thirty five feet (35') in height, except as provided
in section
12-4-3 of this title. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
CHAPTER 11
PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENTS
SECTION:
12-11-1: Intent And Purpose
12-11-2: Regulations
12-11-3: Application And Approval
12-11-1: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
   A.   It is the intent of this chapter to encourage unified design of
housing, commercial, industrial, or institutional areas and facilities, or
combinations thereof, to provide for integrated developments having harmony of
design and variety of function. This chapter is not intended to permit a
greater density or uses different from those set forth in the regulations of
the district in which the development is located, but this chapter is to
provide for a greater flexibility in the design of buildings, yards, courts,
and circulation than would otherwise be possible through the strict application
of district regulations, and to produce:
      1.   A maximum choice in the types of environment and living units
available to the public.
      2.   Open space and recreation areas.
      3.   A pattern of development which preserves trees, outstanding natural
topography, and geologic features, and prevents soil erosion.
      4.   A creative approach to the use of land and related physical
development.
      5.   An efficient use of land resulting in smaller networks of utilities
and streets and thereby lower housing costs.
      6.   An environment of stable character in harmony with surrounding
development.
      7.   A more desirable environment than would be possible through the
strict application of other provisions of this title.
   B.   This chapter is designed to provide for small and large scale
developments incorporating a single type or a variety of residential and
related uses which are planned and developed as a unit. Such development may
consist of individual lots or it may have common building sites. Common land
must be an essential and major element of the plan which is related to and
affects the long term value of the homes and other development. A planned unit
development shall be a separate entity with a distinct character in harmony
with surrounding development. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-11-2: REGULATIONS:
A planned unit development may be authorized; provided, that all of the
following provisions are complied with:
   A.   Location: A planned unit development shall be permitted in any district
except an A-1 general agricultural district, A-2 suburban district, R-1 rural
single-family residential district, R-2 single-family residential district, R-
3 rural mobile home residential district, or an R-4 mobile home residential
district.
   B.   Design Characteristics: The proposed planned unit development shall be
designed to provide for the unified development of the area and in accordance
with the spirit and purposes of the district in which the unit is located. The
design may provide for modification of yard, setback, and height requirements,
but the use, density, intensity of use, and coverage requirements for the
district, and the minimum dimensions established for the design of courts,
shall not be reduced.
   C.   Minimum Site Size: The minimum size of the site upon which a planned
unit development shall be located shall be not less than three (3) acres for
commercial developments, not less than ten (10) acres for residential
developments, and not less than forty (40) acres for industrial, educational,
medical, and other types of institutional developments.
   D.   Off Street Parking: The off street parking requirements set forth in
chapter 12 of this title may be complied with by providing one or more
permanent, common, off street parking facilities for all uses within the
development; provided, that the facility contains the requisite number of
spaces for each use, and that the spaces provided for permanent residents shall
be clearly designated and separated from spaces provided for employees,
customers, and service. The total spaces provided shall not be less than the
sum of the individual requirements and the spaces required for each use, and
shall be under the ownership or permanent control of the owners of the use for
which the spaces are required.
   E.   Site Development Plan; Rezone Request: The developer shall submit a
site development plan of the proposed development in support of the application
for a planned unit development permit. This application shall be considered the
same as a rezoning request, and the same procedures shall be followed
concerning application, planning commission review, and public hearings 1 .
Upon approval by the city council, the site development plan shall become a
part of the zoning district map. The plan may provide for staged development of
the project and shall so indicate on the plan.
   F.   Plan Changes: Any substantial deviation from the plans submitted at the
time of rezoning shall constitute a violation of the rezoning, and substantial
change in plans shall be resubmitted for review following the same procedure
required in the original adoption of the plan. The chief enforcement officer
shall interpret what constitutes a "substantial" deviation or change in the
plan.
   G.   Time Limit: The construction of the planned unit development shall be
started within two (2) years of the effective date of approval of the plan by
the city council. Failure to begin the development within said two (2) years
shall automatically void the development plan, and the land shall revert to the
same zoning classification which existed immediately preceding the approval of
the planned unit development. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
   H.   Homes Association: A homes association shall be created if other
satisfactory arrangements have not been made for improving, operating, and
maintaining common facilities including streets, drives, service and parking
areas, and recreation areas. When required, the owners shall establish a home
association in accordance with state and federal requirements and procedures.
(Ord. 86, 2-16-1982; amd. 2006 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  12-2-3 of this title.
12-11-3: APPLICATION AND APPROVAL:
   A.   Concept Plan:
      1.   Submission: The applicant shall initially apply for a special use
permit by presenting a concept plan to the code enforcement officer. The
concept plan shall be presented for review at a scheduled meeting of the
planning commission.
      2.   Contents: The concept plan shall include types and placement of
residential structure, utilities and public facilities, minimum lot size,
densities, environmental treatment, pedestrian and auto circulation, commercial
and industrial areas, conformity with surrounding areas, homeowners
organizations, financing of project and any other information local
administrators and legislative bodies may require to fain satisfaction of
property development.
      3.   Planning Commission Public Meeting; Recommendations; List Of
Property Owners: The planning commission shall conduct one public meeting
pursuant to application and make a decision, either recommending approval,
denial or approval with modifications. The action of the planning commission
shall be immediately forwarded to the city manager, who shall take steps to
place an approved item on an agenda for hearing at a scheduled meeting of the
city council. Applicant shall provide a list of names and addresses of all
property owners within a three hundred foot (300') radius of the exterior
boundary of the planned development unit to the city clerk for the purpose of
providing written notice of applicant's proposal if approved by council.
      4.   Public Hearing; Notice Requirements: Upon approval by the city
council a date and time for a public hearing shall be set. At least twenty (20)
days prior to the public hearing notice shall be published one time in a
newspaper of general circulation in Carter County and a written notice shall be
mailed to all property owners with a three hundred foot (300') radius of the
exterior boundary of the planned development unit. In addition to written
notice requirements, notice may also be given by posting notice of said hearing
on the affected property at least twenty (20) days before the date of the
hearing. The newspaper and site notice shall contain the following:
         a.   Date, time and place of public hearing; and
         b.   Who will conduct public hearing; and
         c.   Desired zoning classification; and
         d.   Proposed use of the property; and
         e.   Other information necessary to provide adequate and timely public
notice.
   B.   Preliminary Plan: Following approval of a concept plan by the city
council, presentation of a preliminary plan must be submitted and approved
following subsections A3 and A4 of this section. Preliminary plans should be
more specific and detailed including legal description in deed of ownership,
objectives of plan including phasing of residential, public and commercial
areas, future selling and/or leasing intentions and accompanying management
techniques, a base map with topographic identification, environmental features
including water bodies, vegetation and soils, additional maps with lot lines,
location and dimensions of buildings, areas dedicated to public use, layout of
utility systems, and landscape plans.
   C.   Final Plan: Following approval of a preliminary plan by the city
council, presentation of a final plan with recommended modifications and
stipulations must be submitted and approved following subsection A3 of this
section. If the final plan does not deviate substantially no public hearing is
necessary. The final plan should include site plans applicable to legal
recording criteria and engineering drawings. All drawings and plans should be
in detailed character in the final plan. Legal documents such as easements,
agreements, final draft of articles of incorporation, indentures and
dedications shall be submitted.
   D.   Recording Planned Unit Development: Upon final approval the city
council shall accept and record site maps and plans, dedicated streets,
properties, and open spaces and rights of way within the development. (2006
Code)
CHAPTER 12
OFF STREET PARKING AND LOADING
SECTION:
12-12-1: Intent And Application Of Provisions
12-12-2: Required Open Space
12-12-3: Location Of Parking Lot
12-12-4: Joint Parking Facilities
12-12-5: Ownership Or Control Of Parking Lot
12-12-6: Paved Surface Requirements For Existing Structures, Buildings, Parking
Lots And Drives
12-12-7: Construction And Maintenance Of Parking Lot
12-12-8: Number Of Parking And Loading Spaces
12-12-1: INTENT AND APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
It is the intent of this chapter that adequate parking and loading facilities
be provided off the street for each use of land within the City. Requirements
are intended to be based on the demand created by each use. These requirements
shall apply to all uses in all districts. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-12-2: REQUIRED OPEN SPACE:
   A.   Off street parking or loading space shall be a part of the required
open space associated with the permitted use and shall not be reduced or
encroached upon in any manner.
   B.   The area required for off street parking shall be in addition to the
yard areas herein required; except, that the front yard required in a C-
1 Neighborhood Commercial District or an I-1 Light Industrial District may be
used for uncovered parking area, and the front yard of a residential district
may be used for the uncovered parking area for six (6) or less vehicles
associated with a residential use when the area is surfaced with a pavement
adequate to prevent the occurrence of mud and dust with continued use, and may
be used for uncovered area for more than six (6) vehicles in accordance with
the provisions of subsection
12-12-7C of this chapter. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-12-3: LOCATION OF PARKING LOT:
The off street parking lot shall be located within two hundred feet (200'),
exclusive of street and alley widths, of the principal use and shall have
direct access to a street or alley, except as otherwise provided herein. (Ord.
86, 2-16-1982)
12-12-4: JOINT PARKING FACILITIES:
Whenever two (2) or more uses are located together in a common building,
shopping center, or other integrated building complex, the parking requirements
may be complied with by providing a permanent common parking facility
cooperatively established and operated, which contains the requisite number of
spaces for each use. The total number of spaces provided shall not be less than
the sum of the individual requirements. Spaces provided for permanent residents
of dwellings shall be clearly designated and separated from spaces provided for
employees, customers, and service. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-12-5: OWNERSHIP OR CONTROL OF PARKING LOT:
The land upon which the off street parking lot is located shall be owned or
controlled by the same entity which owns or controls the land on which the
principal use is located. (Ord. 86, 2-16-1982)
12-12-6: PAVED SURFACE REQUIREMENTS FOR EXISTING STRUCTURES, BUILDINGS, PARKING
LOTS AND DRIVES:
   A.   Affected Paved Areas, Parking Lots And Driveways: Upon the occurrence
of the following conditions; new construction, transfers of ownership of real
property with paved area, parking lots or on which driveway(s) exist or is to
be constructed, will comply with this Code and all provisions of this chapter.
Any existing paved areas, parking lots, and driveway(s) which are not in
compliance with this Code must be brought into compliance upon the occurrence
of the foregoing conditions. (Ord. 2017-268, 7-17-2017, eff. 7-17-2017)
12-12-7: CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE OF PARKING LOT:
   A.   Size Of Space: The size of a parking space for one (1) vehicle shall
consist of a rectangular area having dimensions of not less than nine feet by
twenty feet (9' x 20'), plus adequate area for ingress and egress.
   B.   Paved Surface Required: All parking spaces required under the
provisions of this chapter shall be paved with a sealed surface pavement and
maintained in a manner that no dust will result from continued use.
   C.   More Than Six Spaces: Off street parking lots for more than six (6)
vehicles shall comply with the following provisions:
      1.   All sides of a lot abutting a residential district shall be enclosed
with an opaque, ornamental fence or wall having a height of not less than five
feet (5') nor more than six feet (6'). Such fence or wall shall be maintained
in good condition.
      2.   No parking shall be permitted within a front yard setback line
established ten feet (10') back of the property line of interior and corner
lots whenever the parking lot is located in a residential district or
immediately abuts the front yard of a residential unit. In all other cases, no
setback shall be required; provided, however, that on any corner lot formed by
two (2) intersecting streets, no parking shall be permitted, and no wall,
fence, sign, structure or plant growth having a height in excess of three feet
(3') above the elevation of the crown of the adjacent roadway surface shall be
maintained in a triangle formed by measuring a distance of twenty five feet
(25') along said front and side lot lines, from their point of intersection,
and connecting the points so established to form a triangle on the area of the
lot adjacent to the street intersection.
      3.   All yards shall be landscaped with grass, shrubs, and evergreen
ground cover and maintained in good condition the year- round.
      4.   Driveways used for ingress and egress shall be confined to and shall
not exceed twenty five feet (25') in width, exclusive of curb returns.
      5.   All of the lot used for parking and driveway purposes shall be paved
with a sealed surface pavement and maintained in such a manner that no dust
will be produced by continued use.
      6.   The intensity of light and arrangement of reflectors shall be such
as not to interfere with residential district use.
      7.   No sign of any kind shall be erected except information signs used
to guide traffic and to state the conditions and terms of the use of the lot.
Only nonintermittent incandescent lighting of signs shall be permitted. (Ord.
2017-268, 7-17-2017, eff. 7-17-2017)
12-12-8: NUMBER OF PARKING AND LOADING SPACES:
   A.   Off street parking and loading facilities shall be provided in all
districts in accordance with the following schedule:

CHAPTER 13
NONCONFORMING BUILDINGS, STRUCTURES AND
USES OF LAND 1
SECTION:
12-13-1: Nonconforming Buildings And Structures
12-13-2: Nonconforming Use Of Land
